The Configuration Persistence Service (CPS) is a platform component that is designed to serve as a data repository for runtime data that needs persistence.

Types of data that is stored:

Configuration Parameters

These are configuration parameters that are used by xNFs during installation & commissioning. Configuration parameters are typically used before the xNF has been brought up or is operational. For example, a 5G Network configuration parameter for a PNFs that sets the mechanical tilt which is a configuration setting upon installation.

Operational Parameters

This operational information could be either an actual state or configuration of a network service or device. These are parameters that are derived, discovered, computed that are used by xNFs during run time AFTER the xNF becomes operational i.e. AFTER it has “booted up”, been installed or configured. For example, in 5G Network, 5G PNFs may need to adjust a tower electrical antenna tilt. These operational parameters are Exo-inventory information, meaning it is information that doesn’t belong in A&AI. In principle, some parameters might be both configuration and operational parameters depending on how they are used.


source:
https://docs.onap.org/projects/onap-cps/en/latest/overview.html

A Technical Action Specification (TAS) consists of a microflow, along with any parameters, conditions, and compensating actions. The TAS is a reference to the microflow that is required to be invoked for each component that requires fulfillment.

Each TAS, unless it is a terminal or final activity in the fulfillment plan, or a branch of the plan, specifies the next TAS to be processed. A TAS is a reference to a microflow and the relationship is N:1, that is, more than one activity may reference the same underlying workflow. Each TAS has a description, which defaults to the workflow description itself.

BPMN.definition:
Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN) is the global standard for process modeling and one of the most important components of successful Business-IT-Alignment.

Standard
BPMN is not owned by a certain enterprise but by an institution (OMG), which is already established through other world-wide standards, e.g., UML. The standard is supported by many software products; you are less dependent on any particular vendor’s products.

Simplicity
The principle behind BPMN is rather simple which is why you can start working with this notation very quickly.

Power of expression
If necessary, you can describe precisely how a process functions with BPMN. However, this is more difficult than only roughly describing the process. This way of precise modeling is possible, but not mandatory.

Implementation in IT
BPMN has been primarily developed to support technical implementation of processes (“Process Automation”). The more important the IT is in a company, the more helpful the use of BPMN becomes.

GBA.definition:
Generic Bootstrapping Architecture (GBA) is a standardized 3GPP technology that enables the authentication of a user. This authentication is possible if the user owns a valid identity on an HLR (Home Location Register) or on an HSS (Home Subscriber Server).

GBA authenticates by making a network component challenge the smartcard and verify that the answer is the one predicted by the HLR/HSS. Instead of asking the service provider to trust the BSF and relying on it for every authentication request, the Bootstrapping Server Function (BSF) establishes a shared secret between the simcard card and the service provider. This shared secret is limited in time and for a specific domain.

Advanced Endpoint Analysis (EPA) is used for scanning user devices for the endpoint security requirement configured on NetScaler Gateway. If a user device tries to access the NetScaler Gateway, the device is scanned for security information, such as operating system, antivirus, web browser versions and so forth before an administrator can grant access to NetScaler Gateway.

The Advanced EPA scan is a policy-based scan that you can configure on NetScaler Gateway for authentication sessions. The policy performs a registry check on a user device and based on evaluation, the policy allows or denies access to the NetScaler network.

Reference:

URI.definition:
URI Syntax

A URI consists of up to five parts. However, only two of these are mandatory.

    scheme: Gives information about the protocol being used.
    authority: Identifies the domains.
    path: Shows the exact path to the resource.
    query: Represents a request action.
    fragment: Refers to a partial aspect of a resource.

Only scheme and path must appear in every identifier. In the URI syntax, all components are listed successively and separated by specific, predefined characters.

scheme :// authority path ? query # fragment

LATA.definition:
Local access and transport area (LATA) is a U.S. telecommunications term that refers to a geographical area of the U.S. assigned to telephone companies to provide communication services. These areas exist under the terms of a Modification of Final Judgment entered by the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia in civil action number 82-0192. This civil action dealt with the break up of AT&T into Baby Bells, or Regional Bell operating companies (RBOCs) in 1982. A LATA is an area in which one of these divested AT&T companies is allowed to provide telecommunications services. According to the court's judgment, Baby Bells were not allowed to provide services across LATAs, only within them.

CPRI is the short form of Common Public Radio Interface. CPRI is popular standard for transporting baseband I/Q signals to the radio unit in traditional BS (Base Station). CPRI allows efficient and flexible I/Q data interface for various standards e.g. GSM, WCDMA, LTE etc.
• eCPRI is published after CPRI. eCPRI standard defines specification which connects eREC and eRE via fronthaul transport network. It is used for 5G systems, LTE-Advanced and LTE-Advanced Pro.

Each user, computer, or security group object receives a unique Security Identification Number (SID) that distinguishes it from other objects in the network. This SID is how that object is identified to the security subsystem in AD. Similarly, each resource in the network — such as printers, files, and servers — maintains an Access Control List (ACL) of SIDs that can access the resource. The ACL consists of entries that detail what type of access (read-only, write, execute, and so on) the user has to the resource. These entries are known as Access Control Entries, or ACEs.

RFID.definition: Radio-frequency identification (RFID) uses electromagnetic fields to automatically identify and track tags attached to objects. An RFID system consists of a tiny radio transponder, a radio receiver and transmitter. When triggered by an electromagnetic interrogation pulse from a nearby RFID reader device, the tag transmits digital data, usually an identifying inventory number, back to the reader.

ECIES.definition: ECIES is a public-key authenticated encryption scheme that uses a KDF (key-derivation function) for deriving separate Message Authentiction Code (MAC) key and symmetric encryption key from the Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) shared secret. It has many variants.

IES.definition: Integrated Encryption Scheme (IES) is a hybrid encryption scheme which provides semantic security against an adversary who is able to use chosen-plaintext or chosen-ciphertext attacks. The security of the scheme is based on the computational Diffie–Hellman problem.

DLIES.definition: Discrete Logarithm Integrated Encryption Scheme (DLIES) is a hybrid encryption system that combines a Key Encapsulation Mechanism (KEM) with a Data Encapsulation Mechanism (DEM).

KEM.definition: In cryptographic protocols, a key encapsulation mechanism (KEM) is used to secure symmetric key material for transmission using asymmetric (public-key) algorithms. It is commonly used in hybrid cryptosystems.

Reference:
https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/tip/What-digital-experience-monitoring-means-for-network-teams

KDF.definition: In cryptography, a key derivation function (KDF) is a cryptographic algorithm that derives one or more secret keys from a secret value such as a main key, a password, or a passphrase using a pseudorandom function (which typically uses a cryptographic hash function or block cipher). KDFs can be used to stretch keys into longer keys or to obtain keys of a required format, such as converting a group element that is the result of a Diffie–Hellman key exchange into a symmetric key for use with Advanced Encryption Standard (AES). Keyed cryptographic hash functions are popular examples of pseudorandom functions used for key derivation.

CMP.definition:
The Certificate Management Protocol (CMP) is an Internet protocol standardized by the IETF used for obtaining X.509 digital certificates in a public key infrastructure (PKI). 

CMP is a very feature-rich and flexible protocol, supporting any types of cryptography. CMP messages are self-contained, which, as opposed to Enrollment over Secure Transpor (EST), makes the protocol independent of the transport mechanism and provides end-to-end security. CMP messages are encoded in ASN.1, using the DER method.

A gate array is an approach to the design and manufacture of application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs) using a prefabricated chip with components that are later interconnected into logic devices (e.g. NAND gates, flip-flops, etc.) according to custom order by adding metal interconnect layers in the factory. It was popular during the upheaval in the semiconductor industry in the 1980s, and its usage declined by the end of the 1990s. 
Gate arrays have also been known as Uncommitted Logic Arrays, which also offered linear circuit functions, and semi-custom chips.

The VXLAN protocol supports the virtualization of the data center network while addressing the needs of multi-tenant data centers by providing the necessary segmentation on a large scale.

RSVP.definition: Resource Reservation Protocol (RSVP) is a transport layer protocol designed to reserve resources across a network using the integrated services model. RSVP operates over an IPv4 or IPv6 and provides receiver-initiated setup of resource reservations for multicast or unicast data flows. It does not transport application data but is similar to a control protocol, like Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) or Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP). RSVP is described in RFC 2205.

IGMP.definition: Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) is a communications protocol used by hosts and adjacent routers on IPv4 networks to establish multicast group memberships. DH.definition: Diffie–Hellman key exchange is a method of securely exchanging cryptographic keys over a public channel and was one of the first public-key protocols as conceived by Ralph Merkle and named after Whitfield Diffie and Martin Hellman

DHE.definition: A cryptographic key is called ephemeral if it is generated for each execution of a key establishment process. In some cases ephemeral keys are used more than once, within a single session (e.g., in broadcast applications) where the sender generates only one ephemeral key pair per message and the private key is combined separately with each recipient's public key. Contrast with a static key.

components within the product being developed.

on PLM system.

detect additional 3PP dependencies of your product that need to be requested to 3PPT. This will allow you to identify new components as soon as they are 
introduced.
Where files are not identifiable the FOSSID service is used to determine whether files are open source, and 'white listing' is available to filter warnings 
related to known files.
The SCAS ordering features provide the functionalities that allows to follow the EPP process to manage the 3PP SW components (FOSS and/or 
commercial) that are known for your Ericsson product - search 3PP SW components (includes FOSS and Commercial), support submission 3PP SW 
requests to 3PPT team and create draft documents for the software vendor list (SVL) and specific evaluations for FOSS components in your Ericsson 
product.

Provider Edge (PE) routers are those routers within a Service Provider core network that connect directly to a router at the customer's site.
In E/// GIC, the Core PE routers are located in the MDAs.  They interface to the WAN, central firewalls and dedicated switches used for the Infrastructure Services Partition. The Core PE acts as ASBR (Autonomous System Boundary Router) connecting the E2C GIC MPLS network to another site MPLS Network and/or External Networks.

OVN-Kubernetes is based on Open Virtual Network (OVN) and provides an overlay-based networking implementation. STEP stands for Standard for the Exchange of Product Data and is also known as ISO 10303. As a common file format used for 3D modelling and printing, these files are an ISO standard exchange format. This means that STEP files can read and save the complete body of a 3D model — not just the basic geometries — which is necessary for high levels of accuracy.
All their 3D model data saves as text that various CAD systems can interpret. STEP files make it easy to create, share, and edit 3D models across many different programs and software in a standardized format.

AFS.definition:
The Andrew File System (AFS) is a distributed networked file system which uses a set of trusted servers to present a homogeneous, location-transparent file name space to all the client workstations.

There are series of Linux/Unix based services which are vital to Ericsson’s development and test at Hubs & sites on 3 continents around the globe. Some of these services depends on AFS. There is a good reason that many people are not aware of the AFS service.

The AFS file system provides a transparent mechanism to supply the application tree, environment files, ARC project environments and toolboxes to Ericsson's Linux/Unix services around the world.

Source: https://wiki.lmera.ericsson.se/wiki/Ericsson_Service-Aware_Policy_Controller/tools/AFS

Andrew File System (AFS) is a distributed file system with built-in replication capabilities that enable users to share files.
It also has a client-side caching feature for faster file loading times. Authentication and access rights are handled with Kerberos.

The AFS storage consists of several Volumes which are independent of each other. Volumes have a quota assigned to it to limit the amount of space consumed.
An AFS administrator could move that volume to another server and disk location without the need to notify users; indeed the operation occurs while files are in use.

Source: https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/GSSLUA/Linux+UNIX+Applications+AFS+Build+Toolbox+Administration+Guide

ILL.definition:
Internet Leased Line Internet versus Broadband Internet - With the evolution of new technologies, the costs of data plans have been falling and businesses have multiple options to choose the basis of Internet connectivity in their offices. Unlike the more common broadband service that is a shared Internet connection, leased lines operate on a private network that is dedicated to the organisation paying for it. This affords the benefits of higher data transfer speeds without any drop in QoS in peak usage times, unlike a broadband connection that can be affected by the activities of other users.

Ref: https://www.tatatelebusiness.com/articles/ill-vs-broadband-choose-wisely-not-hypely/

SANS institute - The SANS Institute (officially the Escal Institute of Advanced Technologies) is a private U.S. for-profit company founded in 1989 that specializes in information security and cybersecurity training. Topics available for training include cyber and network defenses, penetration testing, incident response, digital forensics, and audit. The information security courses are developed through a consensus process involving administrators, security managers, and information security professionals. The courses cover security fundamentals and technical aspects of information security. The Institute has been recognized for its training programs and certification programs. SANS stands for SysAdmin, Audit, Network and Security.

Ref:

OVA.definition:
OVF is a file format that supports exchange of virtual appliances across products and platforms. 
OVA is a single-file distribution of the same file package.

The OVF and OVA formats offer the following advantages:

- OVF and OVA files are compressed, allowing for faster downloads.

- The vSphere Client validates an OVF or OVA file before importing it, and ensures that it is compatible with the intended destination server. If the appliance is incompatible with the selected host, it cannot be imported and an error message appears.

- OVF and OVA can encapsulate multi-tiered applications and more than one virtual machine.

Exporting OVF or OVA templates allows you to create virtual appliances that can be imported by other users. You can use the export function to distribute pre-installed software as a virtual appliance, or to distributing template virtual machines to users. You can make the OVF or OVA file available to users who cannot access your vCenter Server inventory.

Ref: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-AE61948B-C2EE-436E-BAFB-3C7209088552.html

iLO.definition:
Integrated Lights-Out, or iLO, is a proprietary embedded server management technology by Hewlett-Packard Enterprise which provides out-of-band management facilities. The physical connection is an Ethernet port that can be found on most ProLiant servers and microservers.

iLO has similar functionality to the lights out management (LOM) technology offered by other vendors, for example, Sun/Oracle's LOM port, Dell DRAC, the IBM Remote Supervisor Adapter and Cisco CIMC.

Ref: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HP_Integrated_Lights-Out

LOM.definition:
Lights-out management (LOM) is a form of out-of-band management. It enables system administrators to connect remotely to servers and other data center infrastructure to monitor and maintain those systems. With LOM in place, IT teams can keep their systems running and respond to potential problems no matter where they are located, even if they're on the other side of the world.

An LOM system enables data center administrators to manage infrastructure as though they're within physical proximity of the equipment. It lets admins carry out a variety of remote management tasks, such as starting and stopping systems, assessing problems, updating firmware and software, and viewing the event log.

Ref: https://www.techtarget.com/searchdatacenter/definition/lights-out-management

NR-NR Dual Connectivity is a 5G connectivity option where the UE connects to the 5GC using NR only, but with both a master node and a secondary node. 
The master node terminates the control plane from the 5GC (NG-C), and has a control plane connection to the UE. 
The secondary node terminates the user plane from the 5GC (NG-U) and has a user plane connection to the UE, both directly and via the master node using the Xn-U interface.

The Cyber Resilience Act (CRA) aims to safeguard consumers and businesses buying or using products or software with a digital component. The Act would see inadequate security features become a thing of the past with the introduction of mandatory cybersecurity requirements for manufacturers and retailers of such products, with this protection extending throughout the product lifecycle.

The problem addressed by the Regulation is two-fold.

First is the inadequate level of cybersecurity inherent in many products, or inadequate security updates to such products and software.

Second is the inability of consumers and businesses to currently determine which products are cybersecure, or to set them up in a way that ensures their cybersecurity is protected.

Reference:
https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/cyber-resilience-act

CORBA.definition:
The Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) is a standard defined by the Object Management Group (OMG) that enables software components written in multiple computer languages and running on multiple computers to work together.

CORBA is a standard for distributing objects across networks so that operations on those objects can be called remotely. CORBA is not associated with a particular programming language, and any language with a CORBA binding can be used to call and implement CORBA objects. Objects are described in a syntax called Interface Definition Language (IDL).

CORBA includes four components:

1. Object Request Broker (ORB)
    The Object Request Broker (ORB) handles the communication, marshaling, and unmarshaling of parameters so that the parameter handling is transparent for a CORBA server and client applications.

2. CORBA server
    The CORBA server creates CORBA objects and initializes them with an ORB. The server places references to the CORBA objects inside a naming service so that clients can access them.

3. Naming service
    The naming service holds references to CORBA objects.

4. CORBARequest node
    The CORBARequest node acts as a CORBA client.

A standard for building distributed systems, in which different components of a system can communicate with each other over a network. RSA.definition:
RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman) is a public-key cryptosystem that is widely used for secure data transmission. It is also one of the oldest. The acronym "RSA" comes from the surnames of Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir and Leonard Adleman, who publicly described the algorithm in 1977. An equivalent system was developed secretly in 1973 at GCHQ (the British signals intelligence agency) by the English mathematician Clifford Cocks. That system was declassified in 1997.

Reference: Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSA_(cryptosystem)

ViLTE.definition:
ViLTE stands for video over LTE. It’s an extension of VoLTE, which enhances voice services with a high-quality video channel.

ViLTE is conversational – that is person-to-person – video service, based on the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) core network. It has specific profiles for the control and media planes of the video service. Conversational video is also possible via EPC-integrated Wi-Fi – see VoWi-Fi.

To deploy ViLTE, Voice over LTE (VoLTE) is required. It is also advisable to combine ViLTE with RCS to provide the best service offering for consumers.

** reference : 
 https://www.gsma.com/futurenetworks/ip_services/vilte/

PXE.definition:
Preboot execution environment (PXE), pronounced pixie, is a set of standards that enables a computer to load an operating system (OS) over a network connection. PXE can be used to quickly install an OS and is commonly used for both servers and clients. It may also be called PXE boot, boot from network, network boot or local area network boot.

Reference: https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/Preboot-Execution-Environment

MICO.definition:
MICO is a mode of operation for 5G devices. When a MICO activated device is in an Idle state, the 5G network will consider the device to be unreachable. The device will only receive MT (Mobile Terminated) data when it transitions to a Connected state. This transition to Connected whilst in MICO mode is always triggered by the mobile; the mobile will not be paged whilst in MICO mode.
(from mpirical.com)

BWTISHO.definition:
Bandwidth Triggered Inter-System Handover is a function within the NR Traffic Steering feature.
BWTISHO is triggered at initial setup from idle mode. Its purpose is to move UEs from NR SA to LTE when the total NR bandwidth available with the current cell set is below a configurable threshold

BNR.expanded: Best Neighbor Relations for Intra-LTE Load Management
BNR.definition:
The purpose of the Best Neighbor Relations for Intra-LTE Load Management feature is to evaluate whether inter-frequency neighbor cells are suitable for inter-frequency load balancing or inter-frequency offload. 
Suitable inter-frequency neighbor cells are automatically and dynamically configured as load balancing relations. 

It reduces the need for manual configuration of load management relations.
A metric that measures the quality of the relationship between neighboring nodes in a wireless network **This description was AI generated**

SPID.definition:
The SPID is a number from 1 to 256 which is set per subscriber in the HSS. 
It is sent from the HSS to the MME and from there to the eNodeB where it can be used to impact mobility behavior. 
One or more SPID values can be used to differentiate 5G subscribers from non-5G subscribers.

Licensed Shared Access (LSA) and Authorised Shared Access (ASA) are concepts that allow  spectrum that has been licensed for international mobile telecommunications (IMT) to be used 
by more than one entity. Theoretically, this would increase the use of the radio spectrum by  allowing ‘shared access’ when and where the primary licensee is not using its designated 
frequencies. As global demand for spectrum intensifies, regulatory strategies such as these are attracting considerable interest and investigation.

OAT.definition:
Operational acceptance testing (OAT) is used to conduct operational readiness (pre-release) of a product, service, or system as part of a quality management system. OAT is a common type of non-functional software testing, used mainly in software development and software maintenance projects. This type of testing focuses on the operational readiness of the system to be supported, and/or to become part of the production environment. Hence, it is also known as operational readiness testing (ORT) or operations readiness and assurance testing (OR&A). Functional testing within OAT is limited to those tests which are required to verify the non-functional aspects of the system.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_acceptance_testing

OEE.definition: OEE - is the standard rule for measuring manufacturing productivity. It identifies the percentage of manufacturing time that is truly productive. When the OEE score hits 100% it means that the manufacturing process is getting only Good Parts, as fast as possible, with no Stop Time.

XEAD.definition:
Ericsson Customer Active Directory is used as LDAP and authentication source for our customers

XEAD (eXternal Ericsson Active Directory) is based on Active Domain Directory Services

All Microsoft based OS'es in the DMZ are joined to XEAD. 

All customers, external partner users are users in XEAD. (note, TPC not included)

 

<<Benefits >>

XEAD can handle authentication of both external and internal users. This is possible due to a  trust between XEAD to EGAD.

 

<<Limitations>>

Handled only external users and resources on the DMZ
Is situated in Stockholm Data Center only.
An XEAD service account cannot read information of internal users.
 

<<Standard IT Security Guidelines>>

Employees are obliged to follow Ericsson’s directives, policies and instructions regarding handling of company information and assets according to Ericsson Code of Business Ethics.

ABR.definition:
Area Border Routers are routers that connect one or more OSPF areas to the backbone area.
An ABR acts as a gateway for inter-area traffic and it always has at least one interface attached to the backbone area.
For each of the connected areas an ABR must maintain a separate link state database. Only the summarized topology information is  propagated by an ABR to the backbone area.

An Autonomous Boundary Router (ABR) is a router that separates one autonomous system (AS) from another in a network. It uses Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) to communicate with other routers in the network and determine the best path for routing traffic between ASes. **This description was AI generated**

A Product Correction Package (PCP) is a set of documents and materials that are used to correct a product defect or issue. The PCP typically includes the following:

- A description of the defect or issue
- Instructions on how to correct the defect or issue
- Replacement parts, if necessary
- A communication plan to notify customers of the defect or issue

The PCP is typically created by the product development team or the quality assurance team. It is then distributed to customer service representatives, field engineers, and other stakeholders who need to be aware of the defect or issue.

The PCP is an important part of the product recall process. It ensures that customers are notified of the defect or issue and that they have the information they need to correct the problem.

Given the stringent requirements for spectrum efficiency, the BPF benefits from being placed on an SPP. 
The BPF includes user-plane functions that are synchronous to the HARQ loop, including the RLC, MAC, and L1/PHY, and it is also the anchor point for carrier aggregation (MAC) and soft combining (L1/ PHY). 
The BPF contains the per-TTI RRM (fast radio scheduler), and is also responsible for the COMP, for the selection of the MIMO scheme, and for beam and antenna elements.

gNodeB-CU-CP.definition:
The Control Plane function (gNodeB-CU-CP) is one of the separate logical functions of the Central Unit (CU) in the gNodeB. 
It terminates the Xn-C interface to neighboring gNodeBs, and the NG-C interface to the Access and Mobility Function (AMF) of the 5GC. 
It hosts the RRC and the control plane of the PDCP protocols of the Central Unit.

gNodeB-CU-UP.definition:
The User Plane function (gNodeB-CU-UP) is one of the separate logical functions of the Central Unit (CU) of the gNodeB. 
It terminates the Xn-U interface to neighboring gNodeBs, and the NG-U interface to the User Plane Function (UPF) of the 5GC. 
It hosts the user plane of the PDCP and the SDAP protocols of the Central Unit. 
The user plane protocols are used for the implementation of the PDU session service.

Loose Source Routing is an IP option which can be used for address translation. LSR is also used to implement mobility in IP networks.
Loose Source Routing uses a source routing option in IP to record the set of routers a packet must visit. The destination of the packet is replaced with the next router the packet must visit. By setting the forwarding agent (FA) to one of the routers that the packet must visit, LSR is equivalent to tunneling. If the corresponding node stores the LSR options and reverses it, it is equivalent to the functionality in mobile IPv6.
The path between stops on the specified route maybe any length and determined by normal gateway routing.

A Mini Counter Set is an set of counters originating from a mcsProducer in base band. The term is used only in the base band. The counters contains raw data that is forwarded to the OMF layer. In the OMF layer, data from different parts of the system is used to create Performance Measurement data.

Citrix Machine Creation Services is an orchestration component of Citrix Virtual Apps and Desktops that can provide single image management for shared or dedicated machines. MCS is passive component - in most deployments, MCS is involved only in the image build orchestration process (telling the hypervisor what and where to do) and not in daily operations and delivery of images. There are some exceptions to this rule, most notably for hypervisors that cannot automatically reset disks. From a design perspective, environments built using MCS inherits the behavior and characteristics of the hypervisor or cloud provider that is hosting workloads. Design of the MCS environment is therefore heavily influenced by a combination of hypervisor and storage used.

Reference: https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/tech-zone/design/design-decisions/image-management.html#overview-of-citrix-machine-creation-services-mcs

VIP.definition:
Virtual Internet Protocol (VIP) addresses are IP addresses that are not tethered to particular machines. Thus, they can rotate among nodes in a Content Gateway cluster.

It is common for a single machine to represent multiple IP addresses on the same subnet. This machine would have a primary or real IP address bound to its interface card and also serve many more virtual addresses.

You can set up your user base to use a DNS round-robin pointing at virtual IP addresses, as opposed to using the real IP addresses of the Content Gateway machines.

Because virtual IP addresses are not bound to machines, a Content Gateway cluster can take addresses from inactive nodes and distribute those addresses among the remaining live nodes.
Using a proprietary management protocol, Content Gateway nodes communicate their status with their peers. If a node fails, its peers notice the failure and negotiate which of the remaining nodes will mask the fault by taking over the failed node's virtual interface.

Internet-facing applications are programs and services that are accessible from the internet, as opposed to only through an internal network.

Companies set up internet-facing applications for several reasons. Sometimes, they are necessary to interact with customers or partners. In other cases, they are necessary for employees who are either working from home or from out in the field.

Examples of internet-facing applications include web applications, APIs, SSH servers, VPN gateways, cloud services, internet-facing firewalls, or any other remotely accessible services that are either deliberately or accidentally placed on an internet-facing server. Internet facing assets can reside on-premises, in the cloud, or any combination of hosted, managed, or virtualized infrastructure.

Reference: https://www.kroll.com/en/insights/publications/cyber/identify-internet-facing-applications

Citrix
The VDA is installed on each physical or virtual machine in your site that you make available to users. Those machines deliver applications or desktops. The VDA enables the machine to register with the Controller, which in turn allows the machine and the resources it is hosting to be made available to users. VDAs establish and manage the connection between the machine and the user device. VDAs also verify that a Citrix license is available for the user or session, and apply policies that are configured for the session.

The word “VDA” is often used to refer to the agent and the machine on which it is installed.

Reference: https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/citrix-virtual-apps-desktops/technical-overview.html

LXC.definition:
LXC is a well-known Linux container runtime that consists of tools, templates, and library and language bindings. It's pretty low level, very flexible and covers just about every containment feature supported by the upstream kernel.

LXC provides the basic functionality used under the hood by LXD. However, it should not be confused with the lxc CLI client tool provided by LXD.

LXD.expanded: Linux next generation system container and virtual machine manager
LXD.definition:
LXD is a next generation system container and virtual machine manager. It offers a unified user experience around full Linux systems running inside containers or virtual machines.

LXD is image based and provides images for a wide number of Linux distributions. It provides flexibility and scalability for various use cases, with support for different storage backends and network types and the option to install on hardware ranging from an individual laptop or cloud instance to a full server rack.

LXCFS.definition:
LXCFS is a userspace (FUSE) filesystem which offers:

Overlay files for cpuinfo, meminfo, stat and uptime.
A cgroupfs compatible tree allowing unprivileged writes.
It's designed to work around the shortcomings of procfs, sysfs and cgroupfs by exporting files that match what a system container user would expect.

MUST was established in 3GPP Release 13.

DAST.definition: Dynamic application security testing (DAST) is a type of black-box security testing in which tests are performed by attacking an application from the outside. It looks for security vulnerabilities by simulating external attacks on an application while the application is running. It attempts to penetrate an application from the outside by checking its exposed interfaces for vulnerabilities and flaws.

Cognitive Software is a consolidated workspace of modules that work seamlessly together, across the network lifecycle, from planning through deployment and optimization.

It automates operational processes, democratizes the use of AI and by doing so empowers engineers – by freeing up time to focus on the complex problems that require the human brain’s unique ability for creative thinking. cIoT.definition: Critical IoT connectivity is for time-critical communication. It enables data delivery within desired latency bounds. NIS.definition:
In some environments, a Network Information Server (NIS) provides centralized storage and distribution of information that needs to be known throughout the network. In a typical NIS environment, one or more NIS servers are used to centrally manage a set of database maps that correspond to the system configuration files that are commonly found on UNIX systems. For example, there are NIS maps that correspond to the /etc/passwd, /etc/group, /etc/hosts, and /etc/services files. The maps provide the centralized information to a given set of computers that make up a NIS domain.

Each NIS map corresponds to a specific configuration file, such as the /etc/passwd or /etc/hosts file, and consists of a set of keys and values, and a version number for the data. When computers on the network require information stored in NIS maps, they send a NIS client request to the NIS listening port to query the NIS server for the information.

When a computer needs the information stored in a NIS map, it runs the ypbind process to identify and connect to the NIS server best suited to respond to its requests. When the NIS server receives a request, it replies with the appropriate information from its set of NIS maps.

Reference: https://docs.centrify.com/Content/config-nis/NIS_Basics.htm

Whereas DNS focuses on simplification by using workstation names instead of addresses, the Network Information Service (NIS) focuses on simplifying network administration by providing centralized control over a variety of network information. NIS stores information not only about workstation names and addresses, but also about users, the network itself, and network services. This collection of network information is referred to as the NIS namespace.

Reference: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/aix/7.1?topic=services-network-information-service-nis-overview

The Variable Gain Adjustment (Analog domain) provides fine gain control. The dpd gain control loop use the VGA to compensate the gain.
Fine gain control – initial set point from power class.

The radio’s TX analog gain is maintained over temperature via the DPD/txl gain control loop. The forward digital input power at input to DPD (point A) is compared to power from the TOR (point B). The VGA is adjusted to keep power at A and B the same. The power at A is delayed so that observed signal B is for the same tx signal interval.

ToE.definition:
The ToE defines what, within the commercialized Network Product, is to be evaluated. It is defined Common Criteria as "a set of software, firmware and/or hardware possibly accompanied by guidance." 

In CC, the TOE is defined by the vendor. In Common Criteria (CC) evaluations not following a Protection Profile there is a huge latitude for the vendors in this definition, since a vendor may choose to include components in, or exclude them from, the TSF (ToE Security Functions) at free will. This latitude does not exist for SECAM (SECurity Assurance Methodology) since the TSF for the entire network product as commercialized by the vendor is defined by the available and applicable SCASs.

SECAM.definition:
SECurity Assurance Methodology (SECAM) is a process to measure the security features of 3GPP network products studied and described in the present document. 

A SECAM evaluation comprises the Vendor Network Product Development process evaluation, the product lifecycle management process evaluation, and the Network Product evaluation.

The SECAM aims to provide common, verifiable basic security features for different network product classes.

DOIC.definition:
3GPP 29.272
DOIC protects remote servers from becoming overloaded.

DOIC applies a traffic reduction for a specified period following an overload indication received from a remote server. Information about the requested traffic reduction and the duration to be applied is provided by the received overload report, sent in existing Diameter messages. The report also defines the OLP level. This means that the traffic reduction can be applied for the diameter request sent toward the specific diameter host and toward the diameter realm.

UBSan.definition:
UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer (UBSan) is a fast undefined behavior detector. UBSan modifies the program at compile-time to catch various kinds of undefined behavior during program execution, for example:

- Array subscript out of bounds, where the bounds can be statically determined
- Bitwise shifts that are out of bounds for their data type
- Dereferencing misaligned or null pointers
- Signed integer overflow
- Conversion to, from, or between floating-point types which would overflow the destination

EDM.definition:
The Event Data Management (EDM) infrastructure component receives events from various BEAM applications. The events are then processed and exposed to the external system by any of the following interfaces:

Event Publishing – SFTP/Kafka interface that exposes the events with enrichment information in configurable formats.

Event History – The REST based customer care interface, which returns the events with enrichment for the requested entity (example customer/contract/MSISDN).

Customer Snapshot – The snapshot of all the customers in the BEAM system by end of day with their final status and balances are exposed as CSV files and exposed through the SFTP interface in EPS.

Business Intelligence – The events are processed with the scheduled ETL jobs and the results are exposed via the SQL Access interface in EPS.

Event Based Export – The events can be filtered on a scheduled basis and exposed as files through the SFTP interface in EPS.

External files staging – This is an SFTP based interface on EPS that supports the import of events from the system external to BEAM.

Event Data Partition Management REST – This Rest interface is used to mark the movement of customer/user/party from one partition to another partition. This movement can occur within a site or across the site.

DMZ.definition:
Network segment designed to provide an additional layer of security **This description was AI generated**

In computer networks, a DMZ, or demilitarized zone, is a physical or logical subnet that separates a local area network (LAN) from other untrusted networks -- usually, the public internet. DMZs are also known as perimeter networks or screened subnetworks.

Any service provided to users on the public internet should be placed in the DMZ network. External-facing servers, resources and services are usually located there. Some of the most common of these services include web, email, domain name system, File Transfer Protocol and proxy servers.

Servers and resources in the DMZ are accessible from the internet, but the rest of the internal LAN remains unreachable. This approach provides an additional layer of security to the LAN as it restricts a hacker's ability to directly access internal servers and data from the internet.

Hackers and cybercriminals can reach the systems running services on DMZ servers. Those servers must be hardened to withstand constant attack. The term DMZ comes from the geographic buffer zone that was set up between North Korea and South Korea at the end of the Korean War.

Reference: https://www.techtarget.com/searchsecurity/definition/DMZ

PPO algorithms have some of the benefits of trust region policy optimization (TRPO) algorithms, but they are simpler to implement, more general, and have better sample complexity. It is done by using a different objective function.

The Web Services Business Process Execution Language (WS-BPEL), commonly known as BPEL (Business Process Execution Language), is an OASIS standard executable language for specifying actions within business processes with web services. CCE-Al.definition:
The number of resource elements (REs) of a CORESET to carry a PDCCH DCI message is called aggregation level and expressed in terms of CCE. 
each CCE equals to six REGs/RBs (Resource element group or Resource Block )-->6*12 =72 Resource elements (REs)
54 for PDCCH and 18 is reserved for DMRS 

Aggregation levels = 1,2,4,8,16 (one to one match with # of CCEs)

TOTP.definition:
Time-based one-time password (TOTP) is a computer algorithm that generates a one-time password (OTP) that uses the current time as a source of uniqueness. As an extension of the HMAC-based one-time password algorithm (HOTP), it has been adopted as Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) standard RFC 6238.

TOTP is the cornerstone of Initiative for Open Authentication (OATH), and is used in a number of two-factor authentication (2FA) systems.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-based_one-time_password

HOTP.definition: A cryptographic algorithm used to generate one-time passwords for secure authentication and access control **This description was AI generated**

OATH.definition:
Initiative for Open Authentication (OATH) is an industry-wide collaboration to develop an open reference architecture using open standards to promote the adoption of strong authentication. It has close to thirty coordinating and contributing members and is proposing standards for a variety of authentication technologies, with the aim of lowering costs and simplifying their functions.

OATH is not related to OAuth, an open standard for authorization.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initiative_for_Open_Authentication

OAuth.definition:
OAuth (short for "Open Authorization") is an open standard for access delegation, commonly used as a way for internet users to grant websites or applications access to their information on other websites but without giving them the passwords. This mechanism is used by companies such as Amazon, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Twitter to permit the users to share information about their accounts with third-party applications or websites.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OAuth

SSL VPN.definition:
A secure sockets layer VPN (SSL VPN) enables individual users to access an organization's network, client-server applications, and internal network utilities and directories without the need for specialized software. SSL VPNs provide safe, secure communication via an encrypted connection for all types of devices, regardless of whether access to the network is via the public internet or another secure network. 

Reference: https://www.fortinet.com/resources/cyberglossary/ssl-vpn

EEVI.definition:
Third Party Connection (TPC) EEVI

Enable access to assets remotely, share and work with relevant information objects stored in Ericsson systems 'by way of TPC'. 

Use a secure IP connection through standardized connection setup for these external companies to selected and approved systems within ECN.

The external users from the suppliers do not work from Ericsson locations/sites.

Access to Ericsson's information systems or networks from a network outside Ericsson's control (example= suppliers premises) by individuals or bodies who are not part of Ericsson.

Ericsson business wants to establish an IS/IT environment between the external company and ECN at Ericsson according to the Business Agreement between Ericsson and other external parties.

How to setup EEVI (Extended Enterprise via Internet) Remote:  This solution provides External Users the ability to connect to Ericsson from any location in the world. 2 factor authentication is made using Pulse Secure.

Reference: https://ericsson-dwp.onbmc.com/dwp/app/#/knowledge/KBA00190430/rkm

SVW.definition:
A secure virtual workspace (SVW) meets employee expectations, organizational goals and security needs.

A SVW is a protected work environment connecting users digitally, allowing them to access company resources externally while remaining separate from the host environment.

Reference: https://www.itsglobal.ca/secure-virtual-workspace/#:~:text=A%20secure%20virtual%20workspace%20(SVW,separate%20from%20the%20host%20environment.

SVW is a virtual desktop solution for supplier users, where users can access Ericsson applications and resources in a secure way. SVW is Windows based virtual desktop solution and can be accessed from any computer with internet connection. (Read more about pre-requirements below).

With SVW, supplier users will also be able to consume Ericsson Office 365 services, such as Teams, SharePoint and Ericsson e-mail, with their Ericsson identities (SIGNUM).

SVW can only be ordered by a Responsible Person (definition below) for a supplier user in My Support and Services. Initially, onboarding to SVW is being handled centrally by the project team. 

Reference: https://ericsson.sharepoint.com/sites/SupplierVirtualWorkspace

TGA.definition:
The TGA (TOR GAIN Adjustment) provides the fine TOR path power compensation. This has an initial set point based on the power class definition – fine adjustment on top of the TOR step attenuator. The TGA is adjusted to compensate for temperature changes in the TOR path.
Offsets can also be added to the TGA to drive gain changes in the TX path via VGA adjustments in the dpd gain loop.

The TOR step Attenuator sets the coarse gain for the observation loop signal path. This is adjusted based on the power class setting.
This is used in the context of radio planning. It is a detailed analysis of the impact on performance as the load on the network is increased. This is described in the Ericsson Indoor Planner CPI.

PCRM.definition:
Packet Core Security Risk Management (PCRM) is where all security risks are being registered and tracked.
There are three types of risks in the project:

 Feature Security Risks: a security risk that is related to a specific feature. The risk is  identified during feature development work as a result of the changes the feature is making.  Any team member can submit a feature security risk to PCSM board.

 General Security Risks: a security risk that is identified during feature development work but is not the result of the changes the feature is making and is not related to a specific feature.  Any team member can submit a general security risk to PCSM board.

 Product Security Risks: a feature or general security risk that has impacts on the product. A risk at product level, part of the risk list in the product RA&PIA report. These risks are created, maintained and only visible to security general system managers.

OSF.definition:
Order and Sales Final: Orders Booked, Net Sales, Cost of Sales, Unadjusted margin, Closing Backlog. The operative result of our business without any overhead or extra costs.

OSF is usually known as a Financial report.

The OSF is reported in many different dimensions: MA, CU (final destination), Customer, Product Code, Product Area, Selling BA, Selling Company...
OSF1 – 3 = Internal sales between Ericsson companies
OSF4 = External sales from an Ericsson company to an external customer
Consolidated NS only shows OSF4 sales, all internal sales are eliminated
Consolidated Unadjusted margin sums up the margins in OSF1 – 4

DC-C.definition: Also referred as 2-Wire power distribution/arrangement, normally related to -48VDC power supply. The distribution consists of a live conductor and a return conductor that is allowed to be grounded. That means the return current is allowed to be conducted in the ground structure as well.

DC-I.definition: Also referred as 3-Wire power distribution/arrangement, normally related to -48VDC power supply. The distribution consists of a live conductor and a return conductor that is isolated from ground in th remote end. That means the return current not will be conducted in the ground structure/conductor.

DevOps.definition:
DevOps is a compound word for development (Dev) and operations (Ops) that combines people, processes, and technology to continuously deliver value to customers.

What does DevOps mean for teams? DevOps enables previously siloed roles—development, IT operations, quality engineering, and security—to coordinate and collaborate to produce better, more reliable products. By adopting DevOps culture, practices, and tools, teams are better able to respond to customer needs, increase confidence in the applications they build, and achieve business goals faster.

CIFS.definition:
Common Internet File System protocol (CIFS) allows accessing the files over the network, whereas Network File System (NFS) allows remote file sharing between servers.

In the 1990s, Microsoft updated the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol and named it as Common Internet File System (CIFS). The CIFS application uses the TCP/IP protocol and works best on Windows operating systems to share files between machines on a network. Initially, incorporated for file sharing, but now CIFS is exercised for network management and other network services. In this protocol, users or administrators can edit, read, write, or delete files on the remote server. The best part about CIFS is it follows client server methodology as per which you can communicate with any server set to get CIFS client requests.

Reference: https://cloudinfrastructureservices.co.uk/nfs-vs-cifs/

CIAP.definition:
The CIA Method
The most common way to map and know your risks is the CIAP Method: to explain it simply, consider every connection, inside or to your network, as a contract:

- You don’t want your competitors to know what is in your contracts: you want Confidentiality.

- You don’t want anyone to modify the content of your contract (for example, the price agreed upon) without your consent: you want Integrity.

- If you negotiate a contract with the same customer as before, you may want to know what you agreed upon last time. More broadly, you want to know what is in your contract at any given moment: you want Availability.

The method also adds another part to consider (even if people stop at C, I, A): If your contract gets disclosed, destroyed, or maliciously modified, you may want a Proof that this happened, for insurance purposes, for example.

There you have it: the method is named upon its four main components: Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability, (sometimes Proof)

Reference: https://blog.sqreen.com/cybersecurity-risk-assessment-for-startup-cto/

In the context of classifying information based on the information 
security triad of Confidentiality, Integrity and 
Availability and Privacy requirements (CIAP).

CAL.definition: Central ALEX Library Common Access Layer (CAL) In IPOS architecture, a layer within the IPOS COM that translates managed objects into managed resources for simpler development.

Windows
Each user and device that connects to a Remote Desktop Session host needs a client access license (CAL). You use RD Licensing to install, issue, and track RDS CALs.

When a user or a device connects to an RD Session Host server, the RD Session Host server determines if an RDS CAL is needed. The RD Session Host server then requests an RDS CAL from the Remote Desktop license server. If an appropriate RDS CAL is available from a license server, the RDS CAL is issued to the client, and the client is able to connect to the RD Session Host server and from there to the desktop or apps they're trying to use.

There is a licensing grace period of 120 Days during which no license server is required. Once the grace period ends, clients must have a valid RDS CAL issued by a license server before they can log on to an RD Session Host server.

Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/remote/remote-desktop-services/rds-client-access-license
sometimes may also be "call abstraction layer"

ASLR.definition:
Address space layout randomization (ASLR) is a technique that is used to increase the difficulty of performing a buffer overflow attack that requires the attacker to know the location of an executable in memory.  A buffer overflow vulnerability is a flaw in software written in a memory-unsafe programming language, such as C.  Such a flaw is characterized by a failure of an application to validate the size of user input data that is written to memory.  An application can remedy this flaw by checking the length of the user input data and throwing an exception or issuing an error message if the actual length does not match the expected length.

Reference: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/2.4.0?topic=overview-address-space-layout-randomization

PGM.definition: Pragmatic General Multicast (PGM) is a reliable multicast IP transport protocol for multicast applications that require reliable, ordered, duplicate-free multicast data delivery from multiple sources to multiple receivers. PGM guarantees that a receiver in a multicast group either receives all data packets from transmissions and retransmissions, or can detect unrecoverable data packet loss. PGM is intended as a solution for multicast applications with basic reliability requirements. PGM has two main parts: a host element (also referred to as the transport layer of the PGM protocol) and a network element (also referred to as the network layer of the PGM protocol).

GIST.definition:
GIST, in its initial specification for Connection mode (C-mode)   operation, runs on top of a byte-stream-oriented transport protocol providing a reliable, in-sequence delivery, i.e., using the   Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) [9] for signaling message   transport.
GIST assumes other mechanisms are responsible for controlling routing within the network, and GIST is not designed to set up or modify paths itself.
GIST does not handle signalling application state itself, but manages its own internal state and the configuration of the underlying transport and security protocols to enable the transfer of messages in both directions along the flow path. The combination of GIST and the lower layer transport and security protocols provides a solution for the base protocol component of the "Next Steps in Signalling" (NSIS) framework.

YiB.definition: A contraction of yotta binary byte. A yobibyte (YiB) is 2^80 or 1,208,925,819,614,629,174,706,176 bytes. A yottabyte (YB) is 10^24 or 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 bytes.

VERP.definition: Variable Envelope Return Path. A way that email-sending applications can match bounced email with the undeliverable address that caused the bounce by using a different return path for each recipient. VERP is typically used for mailing lists. With VERP, the recipient's email address is embedded in the address of the return path, which is where bounced email is returned. This makes it possible to automate the processing of bounced email without having to open the bounce messages, which might vary in content.

NAPTR.definition:
A Name Authority Pointer (NAPTR) is a type of resource record in the Domain Name System of the Internet.

NAPTR records are most commonly used for applications in Internet telephony, for example, in the mapping of servers and user addresses in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP). The combination of NAPTR records with Service Records (SRV) allows the chaining of multiple records to form complex rewrite rules which produce new domain labels or uniform resource identifiers (URIs).

A2C.definition: AWS App2Container (A2C) is a command-line tool for modernizing .NET and Java applications into containerized applications.

A2C refers to the process or capability that allows users or devices to connect from the access network (such as a local area network or wireless network) to the core network of a telecommunications system.

In a telecommunications network, the access network typically represents the portion of the network that connects end-user devices, such as mobile phones, computers, or other communication devices, to the core network infrastructure. The access network may include various technologies such as wired connections (e.g., fiber optic, DSL, or cable), wireless connections (e.g., cellular networks, Wi-Fi), or other access technologies.

The A2C functionality ensures that traffic and data from the access network can efficiently reach and interact with the core network, which may include elements such as switching and routing equipment, data centers, service platforms, and interconnection points with other networks. This capability is essential for providing end-to-end connectivity and enabling communication services for users and devices connected to the access network.

LINDDUN.definition:
LINDDUN as a privacy threat analysis framework which disaggregates privacy threats into seven core dimensions of privacy:

Linkability: an adversary may link distinct samples of data of interest together without knowing the identity of the data subjects. 

Identifiability: an adversary is able to identify a subject from among a group of subjects using a data artifact of interest. 

Non-Repudiation: the data subject is unable to deny a claim, such as performing an action or making a request.

Detectability: an adversary is able to distinguish whether or not a data artifact related to the data subject exists, even if they cannot access it directly. 

Disclosure of Information: an adversary is able to learn the content of an item of interest about a data subject.

Unawareness: The data subject is unaware of the collection, processing, storage, or sharing activities (and corresponding purposes) of the data subject’s personal data.

Non-Compliance: The processing, storage, or handling of personal data is not compliant with legislation, regulation, and/or policy.

SUS.definition: The Single UNIX Specification (SUS) is a standard for computer operating systems, compliance with which is required to qualify for using the "UNIX" trademark. (source: Wikipedia)

RPD.definition: RPD (Relative Power Drop) is the difference in power level between reference direction beam center and ±60° from reference direction in the horizontal (φ) plane

RBT.definition:
It is a service introduced in some communication networks (PSTN, PLMN, VPN, etc.) to offer different media options to be played before or instead the ringing Tone. 
A specific server provides this service and it requieres a specific  integration to each NW.

ITH.definition: Intelligent Temperature Handling (ITH) is also known internally as “Forced LESS” or “RU Overheating Scheduling''. This is a basic feature that will allow mechanism for overheating RU to lower its temperature by requesting from DU to blank portion of slots which will in turn enable Micro Sleep TX in RU to shut down biggest power consumers, hence lowering temperature.

NodeB.expanded: The logical node NodeB handles the user data traffic and control communication with the RNC and the UE in WCDMA RAN.
NodeB.definition: The logical node NodeB handle the user data traffic and control communication with the RNC and the UE in WCDMA RAN. This includes the handling of cells, channels, and Ethernet links.

TRC.definition: The Transcoder Controller (TRC) node provides the transcoder resources and may be geographically separated from the BSC node. The TRC node supports several BSCs over the Ater interface. The transcoders can be shared between all BSCs associated with the TRC.

GM.definition: A Grandmaster is a highly accurate and reliable time reference in a Precision Time Protocol (PTP) network.

UTF4.expanded: Unified Test Framework of EEA4 (Ericsson Expert Analytics 4)
UTF4.definition:
UTF4 meant to be the Acceptance Test Framework of EEA4.
EEA4 is a microservice-driven mobile network traffic analyzer and data miner tool.

Reference: https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/EInVAut/What+is+this+UTF4

RLO.definition: The part of the Managed Object within the resource layer is called Resource Layer Object (RLO). This is a breakdown of the MOC (Managed Object Class) into parts the system needs to manage. A MOC can consist of one or many RLOs.
Cloud RAN rApp - RAN (Radio Access Network) Lifecycle Orchestrator

C2MC.definition:
Tool is still (2023. Q3) under development and isn't officially released.

C2MC is a test tool for simulating C2 Radios on a COTS (Server). C2MC can be used to verify O&M interface and test DU functionality. It replaces the need to use real radios in test scenarios thus reducing OPEX and CAPEX cost.

C2MC should support FRU enable, Sector carrier unlock and Cell unlock use cases.

It is possible to start multiple instances of C2MC on a single server thus enable scaling the number of simulated radios you need. However, as each simulated radio requires a point to point connection to the DU, the maximum number of radios you can setup (at this time) is:

DU6630/DU6648: 12 SRUs, as these DUs only have 12 RI-ports.

Each simulated radio should be able to support 2 Sector carriers and 2 Cells. Thus allowing 24 Cells with one server.

PLAB.definition: Platform Abstractions (PLAB) has been developed to make it possible to run hosts tests in a native environment which speeds up test time. A description of its' use in the host environment is needed.

AWL.definition:
Aircraft warning lights are high-intensity lighting devices attached to tall structures as collision avoidance measures. Such devices make structures more visible to aircraft, and are usually used at night, although they may be used during the day. These lights need to be of sufficient brightness to be visible for miles around the structure.

Reference: 
https://encyclopedia.thefreedictionary.com/Aircraft+Warning+Lights
https://www.sureall-light.com/product/industrial-aircraft-warning-light/

BFP.definition:
Block floating point (BFP) is a method used to provide an arithmetic approaching floating point while using a fixed-point processor. BFP assigns a group of significands (the non-exponent part of the floating-point number) to a single exponent, rather than single significand being assigned its own exponent.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_floating_point#:~:text=Block%20floating%20point%20(BFP)%20is,being%20assigned%20its%20own%20exponent.

C2-u.expanded: User plane protocol for E-LLS interface
C2-u.definition: C2 “user plane”, the implementation of the C2 functional split as a detailed interface specification of the real-time exchange of data between the eREC and the eRE

C2Full/C2.expanded: Proprietary lower layer split for AAS radios

C2Lite.expanded: Proprietary lower layer split for non-AAS radios

C2L.definition: Proprietary lower layer split for non-AAS radios

E-LLS.expanded: Ericsson Lower Layer Split (same as C2)

NG OLLS.definition:
NG OLLS  ≡ NG LLS 

O-RAN’s proposed concepts and architectures use a split-RAN concept.

HIS.definition: HW Sensitive Install (HIS) reduces the amount of software downloaded to a node to save disk space, bandwidth and download time. Only software that is needed by currently installed hardware is downloaded. LMC files that already exist on the node are not downloaded once again for new UP.

HiCap.definition: An additional feature called High Capacity (HiCap) offers an alternative to the Trace and Error tracing in cases where the EMCA processes to be traced are faster than what the LTTng streaming can support (and traces are lost). It can be selected if traces should be outputted via Trace and Error or via the HiCap feature.

HCMS.definition: RBS CS implements the Health Check Management Service (HCMS) that coordinates the health check jobs. It maintains a list of registered health check jobs and trigger the health check jobs, based on category, towards the health check applications.

RICI.definition: The Radio Interface Control Interface defines services to set up cascaded RE:s, set CPRI link tag, perform delay measurements, update delay values, force clock source port selection, report selected clock source port, fault-handling/SFP information/SFP values over the CPRI interface, PM reporting, get frequency/delay and phase difference between ports, subscribe for port status, read IQ format capacity, configure IQ switching.

RICM-DCI.expanded: Radio Interface Control Main unit - Device Control Interface
RICM-DCI.definition: Radio Interface Control Main unit - Device Control Interface defines services to start/reset CPRI link, start/reset IDL2 link, reset the Radio Unit, set timing status on CPRI (S-bit), establish/release O&M link to RU, reporting DU to RU CPRI link delay, setup/release IQ path, report link fault, start/stop PM reporting, report Ri port and Ri link PM counters, subscribe for RE port sync info, set CPRI link tag, read IQ format capacity, configure IQ&IQC switching, get CPRI link health check information, set SFP filtering, request for CPRI monitoring, get unit identifier for CPRI link endpoint.

INRSI.definition: Inter Node Radio Sync Interface defines services to subscribe/unsubscribe to link status, get phase/frequency difference, get info on if BFN jump is enabled, indicate if there is no CPRI ref clock detected, switch ref clock to CPRI.

EAG.definition: belonging to EAS, the unit of EAS based in Germany, Rosenheim

LITS.definition: Legacy IPC and Task Support interface emulates the mostly used OSE system calls by mainly using pthreads and Linx.

LPEI.definition: Local Program Execution Interface provides services to request allocation of CPU cores (depending on CPU load).

POSIX.definition: The Portable Operating System Interface (POSIX) and the Linux Standard Base (LSB) are two API definitions that describe what user space programs running in a Linux environment can expect to be able to use.

TRI.definition: Trace interface provides a set of macros used for tracing by applications. This interface is compatible with the corresponding CPP interface.

A1 Interface.expanded: Purpose with A1 interface is to send “A1 Policies” from the management system (SMO) to the RAN elements.

A1-P.definition: A1-P (Policy management) contains statements on policy objectives and policy resources applicable to UEs and cells.

A1-EI.definition: A1-EI (Enrichment Information), provided by non-RT RIC to near-RT RIC an/or external enrichment information provided to near-RT RIC by an O-RAN external information source.

EMCA SoC.definition: Ericsson Many Core Architecture - System on a Chip

SFM.definition: Bridge between customer unit and our service domain

TrDevice.definition: Represents the radio function used by one radio carrier.

TR-DCI.definition: Every carrier on the Radio needs to be set up through a O&M signalling interface called TR-DCI. More info can be found at https://ericsson.sharepoint.com/sites/ETKRadioSW/SitePages/TR-DCI-basics.aspx.

ARIB.expanded: Association of Radio Industries and Businesses
Association of Radio Industries and Broadcasting

AST.definition: The ast module helps Python applications to process trees of the Python abstract syntax grammar. The abstract syntax itself might change with each Python release; this module helps to find out programmatically what the current grammar looks like.

CEPT.expanded: European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administration

C-MTC.definition:
Machine Type Communication (MTC) refers to the communication between machines or devices that do not require human intervention. In recent years, MTC has become increasingly important due to the rapid development of the Internet of Things (IoT), where numerous devices are interconnected and communicate with each other.

https://www.telecomtrainer.com/cmtc-critical-machine-type-communication/

CPK.expanded: Columbia Park. Firmware module of NAC

ELH.definition: System developed by the MANA training team to allow users to take training courses

SoCom.definition: Short form for Sourcing Compliance team

TEH.definition:
TEH is under development as of now (2023 Q3)

- System function responsible for STP preparation
- Set of services which will be responsible for all STP preparation
- Currently developed by the ICA team, but designed together with TGF
- Key differences compared to current solution
- Responsible for the entire STP preparation, not just individual components
- Single unified HTTP interface for all preparations
- Preparation is done by providing a desired state (at STP level) rather than actions to be performed
- It’s TEH’s responsibility to find the shortest path to the desired state (e.g., upgrade vs install vs no action)
- It’s TEH’s responsibility to handle dependencies between components and make preparation parallel
- Data required for the preparation is gathered from the appropriate system functions rather then collected by TGF
E.g., TEH will request the necessary artifacts from Artie, not TGF

DFTS-OFDM.expanded: DFT-Spread OFDM (DFT-precoded OFDM, see also SC-FDMA)

FPMTS.expanded: Future Public Land Mobile Telecommunications Systems

UEM.definition:
Unified Endpoint Management (UEM) is a strategy that aims to simplify device and application management by bringing them under a single management platform. MECM and Intune are critical components of Microsoft’s UEM strategy, providing a unified solution for managing all devices and applications. In contrast, SCCM was primarily used for on-premise enterprise Windows environments.

Reference:
https://lachieslifestyle.com/2023/05/27/sccm-mecm-intune/

U-Boot.definition: Open-source, primary boot loader used in embedded devices to package the instructions to boot the device's operating system kernel.

Ater Interface.expanded: The TRC node support several BSCs over the Ater interface.

Chiplet.expanded: A chiplet is a tiny integrated circuit (IC) that contains a well-defined subset of functionality.
Chiplet.definition:
A chiplet is a tiny integrated circuit (IC) that contains a well-defined subset of functionality. It is designed to be combined with other chiplets on an interposer in a single package. A set of chiplets can be implemented in a mix-and-match "Lego-like" assembly. This provides several advantages over a traditional system on chip.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiplet#:~:text=A%20chiplet%20is%20a%20tiny,interposer%20in%20a%20single%20package.

*** Not found anymore in IT Service Catalog ***

Cloud Brokering Management services by Group IT.
Used for integration between Ericsson private cloud and Azure public cloud.

CXA.expanded: An ABC class synonymous with Interfaces and Libraries. See https://abcreg.ericsson.se.

F1.expanded: Feature is approved for pre-study start

F2.expanded: Feature is approved for implementation start

HDX.definition:
Citrix HDX is a suite of proprietary technologies that delivers a high-definition experience to users of virtual desktops and virtual applications. A central component of Citrix DaaS, HDX ensures users have a consistent experience across a wide array of devices and networks. Built on top of the Independent Computing Architecture (ICA) remoting protocol, it’s used by global enterprises to support millions of users.

HDX is designed around three technical principles: intelligent redirection, adaptive compression, and data de-duplication.

Reference:
https://www.citrix.com/solutions/vdi-and-daas/hdx/what-is-hdx.html#:~:text=Citrix%20HDX%20is%20a%20suite,virtual%20desktops%20and%20virtual%20applications.

TbE.definition: Used to describe future speeds of Ethernet above 100 Gbit/s

ABOOT.definition: Application BOOT, an application (e.g. code to control the transmitter) has the possibility with this boot to execute code very early (e.g. to shut of the transmitter).

AED.definition:
The Anatomy of Excellent Development (AED) is an evaluation tool used by R&D organizations to understand their strengths and weaknesses in software system development.

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228823298_Anatomy_of_Excellence_Development

MaxCL.definition: Maximum Coupling Loss (MaxCL) is a term used in wireless communication to measure the maximum loss of signal power between two antennas that can still establish a reliable connection.

MCL.definition: Maximum Coupling Loss (MCL) is a term used in wireless communication to measure the maximum loss of signal power between two antennas that can still establish a reliable connection.

DTA.definition:
Data transfer approval is required before moving data from source system or another IT system/database to a new target system/database. The Information Asset Custodian must be aware of all applications that handles, stores and process their data.
This is essential to ensure proper handling and protection of the information.

Cgroups.definition:
cgroups (abbreviated from control groups) is a Linux kernel feature that limits, accounts for, and isolates the resource usage (CPU, memory, disk I/O, etc.[1]) of a collection of processes.

BMO.definition: Optic transceiver module placed on same PCB

SFP-DD.expanded: Small Form factor Pluggable  - Double Density optics

ETH.definition:
This is the historical name of the Budapest site of Ericsson from the name: Ericsson Telecommunications Hungary Ltd.

SnowOwl.expanded: EMCA SS performing L1BF, BBL1L, NBR processing

QuEST.expanded: Quality Excellence For Suppliers Of Telecommunications

MOCN as MORAN.expanded: This is an LTE single-baseband MORAN deployment using the MOCN configuration where unused PLMN ID are included in the system broadcast but are listed as "reserved for operator use."

A Notice of Inquiry (NOI) will ask the public to comment on specific questions about an issue.

NPRM.definition:
A Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) will propose new rules or changes to existing rules and seek comments on the proposals.
