Multi-TRP.definition:
Multi-TRP (Transmission/Reception Points) comprises several techniques and configurations enabling efficient interworking between TRPs on the same carrier frequency, from a (Baseband Scheduler) resource point of view, for an improved end-user experience.

(Network LP)

SFNC.definition:
A System Function can be divided into one or several System Function Components which can be used to describe further details of the distribution of functionality, internal behaviors, and other properties within a System Function, such as internal restart domains, instantiation of functionality and scaling factors. It is possible to include a System Class in several System Function Components within the same System Function.

This is an optional level.

OCCR.definition: CDRs in ASN.1/BER format based on information received from external rate and charge application.

CNFE.definition: An event with information received from SMF or SMSF that EDM uses to produce CHF CDR in ASN.1/BER format

C2U.definition: C2 “user plane”, the implementation of the C2 functional split as a detailed interface specification of the real-time exchange of data between the eREC(eCPRI Radio Equipment Control) and the eRE (eCPRI Radio Equipment)

PSO.definition: Name of a team/group active in Platform and Dev Ops tools area

RFST.definition:
A remote mechanism to detect PIM (Passive Inter Modulation) as a source of Uplink Interference by inducing a Downlink transmission on all present technologies silumtaneously, while montitoring the Uplink Interference on all cells.

See the following for more information :-
https://eias.internal.ericsson.com/RFST/overview.php

B1.definition:
Inter RAT neighbour becomes better than threshold.
Message reported in RRC MeasurementReport.

CCSP.definition: Skills to implement cloud architecture and design requirements, manage operational and compliance issues, and handle cloud data, applications and infrastructure security.

TRH.definition: It handles LAPD signalling between BSC &BTS, so it could affect the traffic setup. The TRH hardware is RP(RPD/RPG1/RPG2/RPG3), thus TRH is implemented in RP HW and SW.

PEA.definition: Power BI reports about the project

vPCF.definition: The PCF that resides on the VPLMN.

hPCF.definition: The PCF that resides on the HPLMN.

SIP TRKG.definition: SIP Trunking is a service through which IMS operators enable secure connection of IP-PBXs via SIP trunks to the IMS network in static mode connection

ARFCNDL.expanded: Absolute Radio-Frequency Channel Number in Downlink

DCAE.definition:
DCAE is the umbrella name for a number of components collectively fulfilling the role of Data Collection, Analytics, and Events generation for ONAP. The architecture of DCAE targets flexible, plug-able, micros-service oriented, model based component deployment and service composition. DCAE also support multi-site collection and analytics operations which are essential for large ONAP deployments. 

DCAE components generally fall into two categories: DCAE Platform Components and DCAE Services Components.  DCAE Platform consists of components that are needed for any deployments. They form the foundation for deploying and managing DCAE Service components, which are deployed on-demand based on specific collection and analytics needs.

V2N.definition: V2N involves the transfer of data between vehicles and the mobile network, e.g. provides connectivity to the internet

SoW.definition: Core (+ local mngr) + RAN can be deployed as autonomous network

RegEx.definition: A regular expression is a sequence of characters that specifies a match pattern in text. Usually such patterns are used by string-searching algorithms for "find" or "find and replace" operations on strings, or for input validation.

xApp.definition: A software application used by RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) to implement specific functions or services in near-real time within the O-RAN architecture

Optical PCB.definition:
A PCB where the optical layer can be included in the fabrication process of the PCB.

The optical layer may be ‘on top’ or ‘embedded’ in the PCB layers. The optical PCB is an electro-optical PCB including electrical and optical layers, we use the term ‘optical PCB’ to mean that the standard PCB performance is enhanced by the addiction of an ‘optical layer’.​

MISO.definition: Multiple-input and single-output (MISO) is a degenerate case of MIMO when the receiver has a single antenna.

SISO.definition: Single-input single-output (SISO) is a radio system where neither the transmitter nor receiver have multiple antenna.

POPEI.expanded: Point of Presence Engineering and Installation

bpcu.definition: The link spectral efficiency (the net bit rate or maximum throughput divided by the bandwidth in hertz of a communication channel or a data link) is measured in bit/s/Hz or alternatively in bit/symbol, which is equivalent to bits per channel use (bpcu), implying that the net bit rate is divided by the symbol rate (modulation rate) or line code pulse rate (more info see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_efficiency)

SGD.definition:
Stochastic gradient descent (often abbreviated SGD) is an iterative method for optimizing an objective function with suitable smoothness properties (e.g. differentiable or subdifferentiable).

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent)

JV.definition: Template used for invoicing intracampany allocation

AutoML.definition:
Automated machine learning (AutoML) is the process of automating the tasks of applying machine learning to real-world problems.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_machine_learning)

NASNet.definition: NASNet is a type of convolutional neural network discovered through neural architecture search. The building blocks consist of normal and reduction cells.

DSG.definition: A CUDB DSG is a subscriber data partition, the basic distribution unit of subscriber data. CUDB stores every information related to each subscriber in one DSG only, but data related to different subscribers can be allocated to different DSGs.

RLHF.definition:
In machine learning, reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) or reinforcement learning from human preferences is a technique that trains a "reward model" directly from human feedback and uses the model as a reward function to optimize an agent's policy using reinforcement learning (RL) through an optimization algorithm like Proximal Policy Optimization.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback)

Base Model.definition:
A foundation model (also called base model) is a large machine learning (ML) model trained on a vast quantity of data at scale (often by self-supervised learning or semi-supervised learning) such that it can be adapted to a wide range of downstream tasks.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_models)

TSL.definition:
TSL stands for Target Service Library, is inherited from CPP(Connectivity Packet Platform) which is a 3G-platform product from Ericsson. 
TSL is a library/VM that is compiled into the application running RSA-RTE.

mmWave.definition: To explain it we can resort to the simile of highways. The millimeter band is the upper part of the radio spectrum. Because it's on the gigahertz part, not megahertz, any chunk or bandwidth you allocate to an operator to build its own highways is always going to be bigger than any other chunk of the radio spectrum located in the small bands. The millimeter band is something like giving an operator the concession to build a highway in an area where he will be able to widen it as much as he wants.

EDE.definition: (Ericsson Delivery Engine) is web-based tool IMS/VoLTE Online Staging and Node config Generator – EDE

CNIA.definition: A framework hosting tools for VNF TCPDUMP, VNF AppTacing, MTAS Provisionm SBG SMM Manager, NetConf Browser BGCF ENS Analyzer and VNF Alarm Viewer

SALA.definition: NR license-controlled feature, providing a configuration framework to customize link adaptation for different UE groups both in uplink and in downlink. The feature increases the flexibility of configuration for different service profiles to achieve an improved service performance.

C2ET.definition: C2ET is a tool for test and verification of radio units with C2 eCPRI interface. Together with a test framework, C2ET simulates a digital unit. The main functionality of the tool is to playback and capture IQ data, but it can also be used to upload new software to a radio and to communicate with processes in the radio. The tool also acts as a PTP master. The tool has several interfaces for interactive and automated control: GUI, WCF (Windows DLL), and signal interface (LINX GW). For more info see https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/PB/C2ET

EFT.definition: Ethernet Fronthaul Tool (EFT) is a new FPGA/ELSW tool that will be developed based on the TCA platform. EFT has been requested by Ericsson to fill a gap in their module testing of RUs with Ethernet based Fronthaul. The new tool is intended to provide testing capabilities for both O-RAN compatible radios (O-RUs) and C2 radios.

GitCA.definition:
Git as a Certified Archive (GitCA) is a certified store to upload source code in Git repositories. Source code is replicated from Gerrit Central Git repositories to the certified archive. GitCA shall be used as a central store for source code from which Applications SW derivatives are built.

ref: https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/SWCA/gitCA+User+Guide

ETAP.definition: Transport SDN controller and orchestration platform including analytics function for microwave, IP, and optical.

MBD.definition: In Mechanical Deisgn the methodology of using the 3D CAD document as a standalone document to describe a product

Galileo.definition:
Galileo is a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) that went live in 2016, created by the European Union through the European Space Agency (ESA), operated by the European Union Agency for the Space Programme (EUSPA), headquartered in Prague, Czechia, with two ground operations centres in Fucino, Italy, and Oberpfaffenhofen, Germany.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_(satellite_navigation))

BeiDou.definition:
The BeiDou Navigation Satellite System is a Chinese satellite navigation system.

(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BeiDou)

FQPS.definition: FQPS is a sub-function that can turn the transmitter or the receiver on and off within 10 microseconds.

GNU.definition: From Wikipedia: GNU is an extensive collection of free software (383 packages as of January 2022) which can be used as an operating system or can be used in parts with other operating systems. The use of the completed GNU tools led to the family of operating systems popularly known as Linux.

SRAN.definition: Installing a single base station unit that provides the functionality of a new LTE base station and also replaces legacy 2G and 3G base stations.

MTA.definition: MTA is the time defining how long time a Business Continuity workaround can be remain in execution.

REP.definition: A resistor is a passive electrical component with the primary function to limit the flow of electric current

IODE.definition: The IODE number identifies a set of ephemeris and changes for every update of the set. Related to GPS signal.

AMD PDU.definition:
The AMD PDU is used to convey sequentially numbered PDUs containing user data. The AMD PDU is used by the acknowledged
mode RLC entities.

UMD PDU.definition:
The UMD PDU is used to convey sequentially numbered PDUs containing user data. The UMD PDU is used by the
unacknowledged mode RLC entities.

CN AM.definition:
Cloud Native Application Manager defines a set of microservices which together provide the basic application management needs of cloud native applications across SW Onboarding, Configuration Management, SW Lifecycle Management, Data Collection & Processing and Data & Topology Visualization (see Fig 1).

CNAM is not a product (it’s a set of common reusable components which can be used in commercial products) and it’s not a monolith meaning products can choose which components to use in their products.

CNAM.definition:
Cloud Native Application Manager defines a set of microservices which together provide the basic application management needs of cloud native applications across SW Onboarding, Configuration Management, SW Lifecycle Management, Data Collection & Processing and Data & Topology Visualization (see Fig 1).

CNAM is not a product (it’s a set of common reusable components which can be used in commercial products) and it’s not a monolith meaning products can choose which components to use in their products

TAPI.definition: The ONF Transport API (TAPI) project charted under the ONF Open Transport Configuration & Control (OTCC) is responsible for the development of this SDK as an Open Source project.

CN-B IHC.expanded: Cloud Native Base Integration Helm Chart (CN-B IHC)

TMD PDU.definition: TMD PDU consists only of a Data field and does not consist of any RLC headers.

CDK.definition: The AWS Cloud Development Kit is an open-source software development framework developed by Amazon Web Services for defining and provisioning cloud infrastructure resources using familiar programming languages.

ARA.definition:
RAN Optimization--> Cognitive Sw->Virtualized Drive test--> Advance RAN Analytics feature is the feature’s migration from ERA/TPS based tool called xTraces. The aim of functionality is the detailed analysis for the events within calls traces information. The user can find certain patterns in the problematic calls to ease the troubleshooting and network optimization. 

Advanced RAN Analytics is composed of four functionalities:
- Advance & VoLTE RCA
- Traffic Management: KPI analysis
- Traffic Management: HO analysis
- SRVCC analysis

MACH.definition:
MACH Architecture is a set of principles and patterns that define the different building blocks of a new, pluggable and scalable architecture for creating back-end services and modern user experiences.

https://macharchitecture.com/

PPX.definition:
CSIM PPX is an implementation of the RAN node FsUE-PP with the ability to support both the UE and RAN side packet processing function for simulated UEs and nodes (simulated eNB or gNB). 

https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/PB/PPX+user+guide

NAH.definition:
The Network Access Handler (NAH) realizes the User Plane (UP) packet processing of the CSIM simulated Core Network (CN) and the corresponding parts of the simulated User Equipment (UE). The associated CSIM Functions are the Converged Packet Gateway (CPG) and the UE Packet Gateway (UPG).

https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/PB/NAH%3A+Module+Internal+View

AutoFAL.definition:
Automated final assembly line , Tallinn as an example
https://play.ericsson.net/media/id/1_gfpmisyg

PQC.definition: In cryptography, post-quantum cryptography (PQC) (sometimes referred to as quantum-proof, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant) refers to cryptographic algorithms (usually public-key algorithms) that are thought to be secure against a cryptanalytic attack by a quantum computer. The problem with currently popular algorithms is that their security relies on one of three hard mathematical problems: the integer factorization problem, the discrete logarithm problem or the elliptic-curve discrete logarithm problem. All of these problems could be easily solved on a sufficiently powerful quantum computer running Shor's algorithm.

BDMA.definition: Beam-division multiple-access (BDMA) scheme has been proposed to increase wireless communication system capacity and handle a large number of users in 5th Generation (5G) systems.

NGTE.definition: Test System used for radio performance and environmental verification.

CCPC (-SM/-AM).expanded: Cloud Core Policy Controller (Session Management/Access Management)

IOWN.definition: A concept for a future communication infrastructure based on an all-photonics network.

FOCOM.definition: The FOCOM are the logical services provided by the SMO to manage the distribution of O-Cloud software and provides orchestration for O-Cloud life cycle processes.

NFO.definition: The NFO are the logical services of the SMO which coordinates between the O-Cloud for managing deployment life cycle events, open loop, and closed loop operational procedures.

SR-MPLS.definition: The instantiation of SR on the MPLS data plane.

O-Cloud.definition: O-Cloud is a cloud computing platform comprising a collection of physical infrastructure nodes that meet O-RAN requirements to host the relevant O-RAN functions, the supporting software components, and the appropriate management and orchestration functions.

SLCM.definition: Subscription Lifecycle Management (SLCM) refers to the end-to-end process of managing the entire lifecycle of a subscriber's relationship with a telecommunications Service Provider (SP) from initial subscription to eventual deactivation or termination while ensuring service quality, accurate billing, and customer satisfaction. This encompasses all the stages from the initial subscription or activation of a service to its eventual deactivation or termination.

CXL.definition: An industry-supported cache-coherent interconnect for processors, memory expansion and accelerators.

FiGHT.definition:
A knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques for 5G systems which serves as a foundation to 5G security research.

A registered trademark of The MITRE Corporation.

Kubectl.definition: Command line tool for communicating with a Kubernetes cluster's control plane, using the Kubernetes API

AHT.definition:
In the context of artificial intelligence, Ad hoc teamwork is the well-established research problem of designing agents that can collaborate with new teammates without prior coordination.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.10450

EPPIC.expanded: Ericsson Partner Portal for Invoicing Claims

UPN.definition:
In Windows Active Directory, a User Principal Name (UPN) is the name of a system user in an email address format. A UPN (for example: john.doe@domain.com) consists of the user name (logon name), separator (the @ symbol), and domain name (UPN suffix).

Important:
A UPN is not the same as an email address. Sometimes, a UPN can match a user's email address, but this is not a general rule. 

Reference: https://www.codetwo.com/kb/upn/

EGD.definition:
EGD stands for Ericsson Global Directory and is a meta-directory service, that governs the flow of data between one or more directory services and databases, and sync data real time in different downstream systems.


EGD stands for Ericsson Global Directory and is a meta-directory service. A meta-directory system provides the flow of data between one or more directory services and databases, in order to maintain synchronization of that data, and is an important part of identity management systems

The EGD service consist of both directory server and meta-directory where directory server is an LDAP based server and used as data repository while meta directory service is used to sync data between EGD and downstream applications. EGD contains users data like Workforce, External users & functional identities, it also contains Ericsson internal organization data and external user company data.

Reference: https://ericsson-is.onbmc.com/innovationsuite/index.html#/com.ericsson02.Portal/iview/com.ericsson02.Portal:CommonView_Standard?param=AGGI9BY7BFW9HAQMT9IBQLVBXGOLWL&param=EGD%20-%20Ericsson%20Global%20Directory&param=AGGFDQSPEZB36AQOYSKHQOAH1LS5XG

ERPS.definition: Help achieve high reliability and network stability with avoiding link loops that cause broadcasting.

UBG.definition:
UBG (User Behavior Generator) is a CSIM module product that creates UEs and controls their behaviors via behavioral models:

- mobility behavior - defines the way the UE moves in the defined area
- equipment-control behavior - defines when and under what conditions the UE turns the power on/off
- application behavior - defines traffic generated by the UE

https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/PB/UBG+-+Module+External+View

APN-NI.definition: The APN-NI is a mandatory part of the APN, which defines the PDN connectivity and services requested by the UE. An APN-NI corresponds to an internet domain name to guarantee the uniqueness of APN-NIs between PLMNs. The MME selects the APN-NI according to the UE requested information, subscription data, and MME local configuration

APN-OI.definition: The APN-OI is the domain name of the operator. For a home subscriber, the MME selects the APN-OI based on the configured IMSI number series. For a roaming subscriber, the APN-OI is based on the IMSI number series configuration in the MME if the PDN is home routed. For local breakout, the APN-OI is based on the PLMN-ID of the current location of the UE.

EFI.definition: The EFI (Extensible Firmware Interface) system partition or ESP is a partition on a data storage device (usually a hard disk drive or solid-state drive) that is used by computers having the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI).

IRF.definition: Recruiters indicates in this form the needed details for scheduling request.

Interview Placeholder.definition: If no date and time provided by the recruiter, these invitations must send to the interviewer and candidate with the scheduler proposed interview schedule based on the interviewer's availability via Scheduling Assistant.

FLACC.definition:
Informal:
A special compiler for the C programming language used by Ericsson baseband developers for custom ASIC chips that are used in Ericsson products.

SHP.definition: Hysteresis refers to the difference in voltage levels between the detection of a transition from a logic low level to a logic high level and the transition from a logic high level to a logic low level.

SECaaS.definition: Security as a service is a business model in which a service provider integrates their security services into a corporate infrastructure on a subscription basis more cost-effectively than most individuals or corporations can provide on their own when the total cost of ownership is considered.

MLM.definition: Masked language models (MLMs) are used in natural language processing (NLP) tasks for training language models. Certain words and tokens in a specific input are randomly masked or hidden in this approach and the model is then trained to predict these masked elements by using the context provided by the surrounding words.

WACC.definition: Weighted average cost of capital (WACC) is the average after-tax cost of capital a company expects to pay to finance its assets, including common stock, preferred stock, bonds, and other forms of debt.

BGP-LS.definition: A mechanism by which link-state and traffic engineering information can be collected from networks and shared with external components using the BGP routing protocol.

LSDB.definition: The link state database used by link state routing protocols such as OSPF and IS-IS.

KEK.definition: A key that encrypts other key. Other names, Master key or Primary key

AON.definition: Microsoft Azure Operator Nexus is a carrier-grade hybrid cloud platform built for mission-critical mobile network applications

ALPN.definition: A TLS extension that permits the application layer to negotiate protocol selection within the TLS handshake. For instances in which multiple application protocols are supported on the same TCP or UDP port, this extension allows the application layer to negotiate which protocol will be used within the TLS connection.

ETAC.definition: Cloud-native transport automation software product that uses AI and ML to analyze, automate and control microwave, IP and optical fronthaul networks.

PMRM.definition: The PM resource monitor gets CPU/Memory usage related information from Kubernetes API Server, and reports CPU/Memory usage metrics to PM Server.

REILI.expanded: RBS CS to ENM Instantaneous Licensing Interface

FECAD.definition: This is a team that makes tools and support with Infrastrucutre and tool

FOM.definition: Manager taking care of one Field Operations Office.

BBF.definition: An open, non-profit industry organization composed of the industry’s leading broadband operators, vendors, and thought leaders. It focuses on accelerating broadband innovation, standards, and ecosystem development.

CP/M.definition: CP/M, originally standing for Control Program/Monitor and later Control Program for Microcomputers, is a mass-market operating system created in 1974 for Intel 8080/85-based microcomputers. Initially confined to single-tasking on 8-bit processors and no more than 64 kilobytes of memory, later versions of CP/M added multi-user variations and were migrated to 16-bit processors.

MASQUE.expanded: Multiplexed Application Substrate over QUIC Encryption

ASLR-NG.expanded: Address Space Layout Randomisation - Next Generation
ASLR-NG.definition: Address Space Layout Randomisation - Next Generation is newer ASLR technique for user address space that should be an improvement over original ASLR. It is implemented by researchers in kernel 4.15.

AMPR.definition: A-MPR (Additional Maximum Power Reduction) is a feature in LTE (Long-Term Evolution) cellular networks that enables mobile operators to further reduce the maximum transmit power of mobile devices beyond what is specified in the standard. The purpose of A-MPR is to enhance the efficiency of the network and improve the overall performance of the LTE system.

DFF.expanded: Design for Fabrication of the PCB

CTI.definition: An O-RAN defined optional interface between O-DUs and Transport Nodes that is used to interconnect the O-DUs to a variety of O-RUs. The idea is to support real-time and non-real time cooperation between the eNB/gNB and the resource allocation based transport networks.

PMIC.definition: ENM Performance Management Initiation and Collection (PMIC) enables a user to initiate and manage counter and event output jobs, and to produce the resultant files.

NHM.definition: An ENM application which provides an overview of the current network health data, including configuration state data, alarm data, and Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

NHA.definition: An ENM application which is part of Network Health Monitor (NHM). The Network Health Analysis web-based application allows the users to monitor a refined set of Network Elements providing CM state, FM Alarm and KPI data on a node-by node basis or node-by node and object-by object basis.

OWAMP.definition: A protocol for active measurements of unidirectional characteristics such as one-way delay and one-way loss.

FRAND.definition: Denotes a voluntary licensing commitment that standards organizations often request from the owner of an intellectual property right.

IDUN.definition:
Idun (or IDUN) is an internal name of EIAE (Ericsson Intelligent Automation Engine) and since Ericsson is a Swedish company, has a trend of naming things after Norse Gods.
Idun is described as the wife of the skaldic god Bragi, and in the Prose Edda, also as a keeper of apples and granter of eternal youthfulness. The name has been variously explained as meaning "ever young", "rejuvenator", or "the rejuvenating one".

XWP.definition: A portal for external workforce to do time reporting and other administrative actions.

EG8.definition:
External resources employed by an external supplier and fulfilling any of the following criteria.
 - Not managed by Ericsson
 - Not selected as an individual (a sourced service or a subcontractor)
 - Use their own office and equipment (only)

SGAC.definition: SGAC is the short form of name of the central datacenter in Singapore.  It stands for SinGapore Ayer rajah Crescent.

KPIM.definition: An application in ENM for managing KPIs (Key Performance Indicators).

PKIPM.definition: An Ericsson Network Manager (ENM) application that enables management of Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) certificate, trust and entity profiles through a web interface.

PKIEM.definition: An Ericsson Network Manager (ENM) application that enables management of Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) Certificate Authority Entities and End Entities through a web interface.

ENMaaS.expanded: Ericsson Network Manager as a Service

ECDH.definition: Elliptic-Curve Diffie–Hellman  is a key agreement protocol that allows two parties, each having an elliptic-curve public–private key pair, to establish a shared secret over an insecure channel. This shared secret may be directly used as a key, or to derive another key. The key, or the derived key, can then be used to encrypt subsequent communications using a symmetric-key cipher. It is a variant of the Diffie–Hellman protocol using Elliptic-Curve Cryptography (ECC).

LZW.definition: Lempel–Ziv–Welch is a universal lossless data compression algorithm created by Abraham Lempel, Jacob Ziv, and Terry Welch. It was published by Welch in 1984 as an improved implementation of the LZ78 algorithm published by Lempel and Ziv in 1978. The algorithm is simple to implement and has the potential for very high throughput in hardware implementations. It is the algorithm of the Unix file compression utility compress and is used in the GIF image format.

RIIR.definition: Phrase used to suggest rewriting a project or application in the Rust programming language that is currently written in some other language.

TOD.definition:
Trade Order Desk (TOD) validates and secures that Ericsson company is following valid trade compliance regulations.

TOD handels and approves requests regarding:
- Travel Booking
- Customer Support
- Supplier Authorization
- Support

EDCS.definition: EDCS (Ericsson Dedicated Customer Support) is an internal tool created by Ericsson to handle standard severity CSRs.

EPS-AKA.expanded: Evolved Packet System - Authentication and Key Agreement

EAP-AKA'.expanded: Extensible Authentication Protocol - Authentication and Key Agreement

TDF-C.expanded: Traffic Detection Function Control plane function

BLD.definition:
This is a Blended Training, consisting of Digital Learning and Live Training components.

The Digital Learning component is based on self-paced interactive learning with multimedia content, delivered online, and the Live Training component is based on theoretical instructor-led lessons.

PEIM.definition:
Learning program for SDM's. Best in Class emergency reduction program with Post Emergency Management. 
2 day learning course.

CBRS-DC.definition: Citizens Broadband Radio Service Domain Coordinator is an Ericsson network service that requests grants on behalf of the radios and programs the cells.

FRS.definition: The Family Radio Service is an improved walkie-talkie radio system authorized in the United States since 1996. This personal radio service uses channelized frequencies around 462 and 467 MHz in the ultra high frequency (UHF) band.
In the context of Active Directory.

GMRS.definition: The General Mobile Radio Service is a land-mobile FM UHF radio service designed for short-range two-way voice communication and authorized under part 95 of the US FCC code. It requires a license in the United States, but some GMRS compatible equipment can be used license-free in Canada.

MURS.definition:
In the United States, the Multi-Use Radio Service is a licensed by rule two-way radio service similar to the Citizens Band (CB).
MURS is a private, two-way, short-distance voice or data communications service for personal or business activities of the general public that operats in a narrow selection of the VHF band, with a power limit of 2 watts.

TCP/IP.definition: The Internet Protocol suite. Set of standards defined by IETF for the Internet and similar IP-based networks.

EDEC.definition: Accelerates the onboarding and validation of multivendor Products and Services reducing their time to market (TTM).

E-Line.definition: An Ethernet service type defined by MEF for connecting exactly 2 UNIs where those 2 UNIs can communicate only with one another. The service is based on a Point-to-Point Ethernet Virtual Connection.

E-LAN.definition: A multipoint-to-multipoint Ethernet service defined by MEF that connects a number of UNIs (2 or more) providing full mesh connectivity for those sites. Each UNI can communicate with any other UNI that is connected to the same E-LAN service.

E-Tree.definition: An E-Tree is a rooted multipoint Ethernet service defined by MEF that connects a number of UNIs providing sites with hub and spoke multipoint connectivity. Each UNI is designated as either root or leaf. A root UNI can communicate with any leaf UNI, while a leaf UNI can communicate only with a root UNI.

EP-LAN.definition: A port based E-LAN service based on a Multipoint-to-Multipoint EVC. The service is defined in MEF 6.1 Technical Specification.

EP-Tree.definition: A port based E-Tree service based on a Rooted-Multipoint EVC. The service is defined in MEF 6.1 Technical Specification.

EVP-Tree.definition: A VLAN based E-Tree service based on a Rooted-Multipoint EVC, where the EVC is identified by VLAN ID. The service is defined in MEF 6.1 Technical Specification.

EVP-LAN.definition: A VLAN based E-LAN service based on a Multipoint-to-Multipoint EVC, where the EVC is identified by VLAN ID. The service is defined in MEF 6.1 Technical Specification.

EVPL.definition: A VLAN based E-Line service based on a Point-to-Point EVC, where the EVC is identified by VLAN ID. The service is defined in MEF 6.1 Technical Specification.

SPIFHO.definition: The feature enables voice service (VoLTE or PTT) on an LTE network with frequency bands where the voice service is prohibited by the frequency assignment authority.

TOOS.definition: It is when a base station is purposely blocked from being connected to the network and set to TOOS in the Network Management System, with the intention of bringing it back into service (Live) after the reason for it being TOOS has been resolved.

CCMS.definition: A component content management system (CCMS) is a content management system that manages content at a granular level (component) rather than at the document level. Each component represents a single topic, concept or asset (for example an image, table, product description, a procedure).

GRO.definition: Generic Receive Offload (GRO) is a widely used SW-based offloading technique to reduce per-packet processing overheads. By reassembling small packets into larger ones, GRO enables applications to process fewer large packets directly, thus reducing the number of packets to be processed.

MOshell.definition: An Ericsson proprietory scripting language used for programming and automating tasks in telecommunications networks. It allows operators to customize the behavior of network elements and automate repetitive tasks.  AMOS (Advanced Moshell) is its customer friendly sibling.

PQD.definition: PQD is a tool to analyze the Product Quality for Product(s), how well the product adhere to the new Ericsson Product Quality Framework.

IBM.definition: The International Business Machines Corporation (doing business as IBM), nicknamed Big Blue, is an American multinational technology corporation headquartered in Armonk, New York and is present in over 175 countries.

C64.definition:
The Commodore 64 is an 8-bit home computer introduced in January 1982 by Commodore International.
The C64 took its name from its 64 kilobytes (65,536 bytes) of RAM. With support for multicolor sprites and a custom chip for waveform generation, the C64 could create superior visuals and audio compared to systems without such custom hardware. 
It has been listed in the Guinness World Records as the highest-selling single computer model of all time, with independent estimates placing the number sold between 12.5 and 17 million units.

GIGO.definition: In computer science, Garbage In, Garbage Out is the concept that flawed, or nonsense (garbage) input data produces nonsense output.

FPV.definition: An FPV drone is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) with a camera that wirelessly transmits video feed to goggles, a headset, a mobile device or another display. The user has a first-person view (FPV) of the environment where the drone flies and may capture video or still images.

AGI.definition: An Artificial General Intelligence is a hypothetical type of intelligent agent. If realized, an AGI could learn to accomplish any intellectual task that human beings or animals can perform. Alternatively, AGI has been defined as an autonomous system that surpasses human capabilities in the majority of economically valuable tasks.

CATT.definition: Datang Telecom Technology Co., Ltd., known as Datang Telecom or DTT, is a Chinese listed company based in Beijing, China. It is a subsidiary of state-owned "China Academy of Telecommunications Technology" (CATT), which had a trading name Datang Telecom Group.

VAST.definition: Visual, Agile and Simple Threat (VAST) is an automated threat modeling process applied to either application threats or operational threats. To model application threats, VAST diagrams the threat to the architecture of the system. To model operational threats, VAST diagrams the threat from the attacker's perspective.

PASTA.expanded: Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis
PASTA.definition: PASTA is an acronym that stands for Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis. It is a 7-step risk-based threat modeling framework. There are several other threat modeling frameworks, however others were deemed either too focused on coding or too focused on attacks.

DREAD.expanded: Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected Users, and Discoverability.
DREAD.definition: DREAD is a framework that can be used to evaluate and triage various threats by rating them on an ordinal scale. The framework is broken into five main categories: Damage, Reproducibility, Exploitability, Affected Users, and Discoverability.

SQUARE.definition: Security Quality Requirements Engineering (SQUARE) is a nine-step process that helps organizations build security, including privacy, into the early stages of the production lifecycle.

Seccomp.definition: Seccomp(Secure computing) is a Linux kernel feature to restrict the system calls that a process can make. Docker, by default, uses this feature to block unsafe system calls. The default profile is moderately safe and blocks around 51 of 300+ system calls.

PC-MM.definition: Service in PCC, which includes MME and AMF.

PC-SM.definition: Service in PCC, which includes SGW-C, PGW-C and SMF.

RGB.definition:
The RGB color model is an additive color model in which the red, green and blue primary colors of light are added together in various ways to reproduce a broad array of colors. 
The main purpose of the RGB color model is for the sensing, representation, and display of images in electronic systems, such as televisions and computers, though it has also been used in conventional photography. Before the electronic age, the RGB color model already had a solid theory behind it, based in human perception of colors.

LCNC.definition: Low-code and no-code development platforms are tools for people who either do not know how to code or have no time to code. Whereas these low-code and no-code frameworks are built on actual coding languages like PHP, Python, and Java, end users are not concerned with the specifics.

SGID.definition: SGID, which stands for Set Group ID, is another special permission that can be applied to executable files and directories. When an executable file has the SGID permission enabled, it allows users who execute the file to temporarily assume the group ownership of the file.

SUID.definition: SUID: It is special file permission for executable files.

wget.definition: GNU Wget is a computer program that retrieves content from web servers. It is part of the GNU Project. Its name derives from "World Wide Web" and "get". It supports downloading via HTTP, HTTPS, and FTP.

NGFW.definition: A Next-Generation Firewall is a security appliance that processes network traffic and applies rules to block potentially dangerous traffic. NGFWs evolve and expand upon the capabilities of traditional firewalls. They do all that firewalls do, but more powerfully and with additional features.

NDR.definition: Network Detection and Response technology emerged in the early 2010s to identify and stop evasive network threats that couldn't be easily blocked using known attack patterns or signatures. NDR, also referred to as Network Traffic Analysis (NTA), technology uses machine learning and behavioral analytics to monitor network traffic and develop a baseline of activity. Then they discover anomalous activity associated with malware, targeted attacks, insider abuse, and risky behavior.

NTA.definition:
Network Traffic Analysis is a method of monitoring network availability and activity to identify anomalies, including security and operational issues. Common use cases for NTA include:
 - Collecting a real-time and historical record of what’s happening on your network
 - Detecting malware such as ransomware activity
 - Detecting the use of vulnerable protocols and ciphers
 - Troubleshooting a slow network
 - Improving internal visibility and eliminating blind spots

DLP.definition: Data Loss Prevention is a security solution that identifies and helps prevent unsafe or inappropriate sharing, transfer, or use of sensitive data. It can help organization to monitor and protect sensitive information across on-premises systems, cloud-based locations, and endpoint devices.

DEAL.definition: Artificial Inteligence (AI) technique that use highly mathematical and innovative approach that allows for the nuanced understanding of emotional states through auditory data.

OBF.definition: Out of Box Failure means the units reported by the customer that are failing on site after initial installation/integration.

FNN.definition: A feedforward neural network (FNN) is one of the two broad types of artificial neural network, characterized by direction of the flow of information between its layers. Its flow is uni-directional, meaning that the information in the model flows in only one direction—forward—from the input nodes, through the hidden nodes (if any) and to the output nodes. WIKIPEDIA

IDAN.definition:
Intent-driven autonomous networks are network systems that are designed to operate based on high-level goals or objectives set by network operators, instead of low-level configuration details.

These networks use machine learning and artificial intelligence to understand the operator’s intent and then make decisions and take actions to achieve that intent automatically. The goal of intent-driven autonomous networks is to simplify network operations, improve efficiency and reliability, and reduce human error. The focus is on what the network should do, rather than how it should do it, which enables operators to manage their networks at a higher level of abstraction.

ALL.definition: Review all activities undertaken during the ageement lifecycle management phase

ASSP.definition: Like an ASIC but a more general-purpose device

vCAF.definition: Part of 5G converged charging system which provides the service-based interface to the network elements and maintains session and event data, interfacing to enhanced versions of the SDP nodes.

HQL.definition:
The Hydra Query Language (HQL for short) is a quick way to find things that might have been difficult otherwise. For example, if you want to find all CIs that have a hardware model with more than 2 slots.

Reference: https://hydra.gic.ericsson.se/user-guide/search/hql

GBL.definition:
In the context of Business Critical Transformation and the Detailed Application Guidelines (DAG).

Reference: https://ericsson.sharepoint.com/:p:/r/sites/BusinessCriticalAreas57/Shared%20Documents/Communication%20%26%20Implementation%20Assets%20-%20FOR%20USE/Business%20Critical%20Transformations%20overview%20and%20activation%20plan.pptx?d=w6a415fc3e99c49a4a3efd34ebd1c915e&csf=1&web=1&e=uX8yaU

CCO.definition:
Chief compliance officers (CCOs) are responsible for designing, implementing and monitoring the processes by which the company will comply with all applicable laws and regulations.

Reference: https://www.chief-compliance-officer.org/

IMK.definition: The Installation Maintenance Kit (IMK) – an android application developed by MMEA BUILD – is developed to improve the efficiency of commissioning radio sites. With IMK, deployments can be handled remotely in the smartest possible way.

VCP.definition: Verizon Cloud Platform (VCP), on which the 5G core is built, is based on a Webscale software architecture with advanced IP-based technologies designed specifically for telco workloads.

RSTD.definition:
The UE measurement for OTDOA positioning is the Reference Signal Time Difference Measurement (RSTD), specified in 3GPP TS 36.214. 
The RSTD is defined as the relative timing difference between two cells – the reference cell and a measured cell – calculated as the smallest time difference between two subframe boundaries received from the two different cells.

UL-RTOA.expanded: Up Link - Relative Time of Arrival

SOAR.definition:
Security orchestration, automation and response (SOAR) technology helps coordinate, execute and automate tasks between various people and tools all within a single platform. This allows organizations to not only quickly respond to cybersecurity attacks but also observe, understand and prevent future incidents, thus improving their overall security posture.

A comprehensive SOAR product, as defined by Gartner, is designed to operate under three primary software capabilities: threat and vulnerability management, security incident response, and security operations automation.

SQR.definition: There are some criteria that determine the software level quality (1-5)

IBA.definition: The TeleManagement Forum (TM Forum) defines intent as “the formal specification of all expectations including requirements, goals, and constraints given to a technical system.” RAN intents are based on overall CSP business intents and priorities with the specific purpose of guiding the RAN automation solution to optimize its behavior given a set of deployed resources (sites, sector carriers, transport capacity, software licenses and so on).

ODA.definition:
Open Digital Architecture (ODA) is a standardized cloud-native enterprise architecture blueprint for all elements of the industry from Communication Service Providers (CSPs), through vendors to system integrators. It accelerates the delivery of next-gen connectivity and beyond - unlocking agility, removing barriers to partnering, and accelerating concept-to-cash.

https://www.tmforum.org/oda/

S-DPD.definition: A digital pre-distortion architecture where two or more pre-distorters operate in parallel over different input streams. Used e.g., in multiband linearization.

ChatGPT.definition: ChatGPT is an AI-powered language model developed by OpenAI, capable of generating human-like text based on context and past conversations.

TMCT.definition:
TMCT is a SharePoint Task Lifecycle Management Tool that was developed inhouse specifically to provide a secure, single repository to register tax events in Ericsson. It’s user friendly and will help us all to prove we are in control. 
https://ericsson.sharepoint.com/sites/TMCT/SitePages/Task_Management.aspx

4pp.definition: A term sometimes used for the suppliers for the 3rd party providers.

CWE.definition: A community-developed list of software and hardware weakness types. See https://cwe.mitre.org/

ENISA.expanded: The European Union Agency for Cybersecurity
ENISA.definition: ENISA, is the European Union’s agency dedicated to achieving a high common level of cybersecurity across Europe.

IAST.definition: Application security testing method that tests the application while the app is run by an automated test, human tester, or any activity “interacting” with the application functionality.

dca.definition: Dynamic code analysis is the method of debugging by examining an application during or after a program is run.

KR.definition: Delivery units and devices for Radio Communication (KRA, KRB, KRC and KRD)

PSDAP.definition: PS DAP is the solution to replace Vul Hub and SE Dash

BETA.definition:
A tool to analyze L2 baseband Cloud RAN lttng traces and generate summary tables and graphs.

https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=1761906102

VTAP.definition:
Analyzing Baseband L2 lttng traces in Cloud RAN vDU. It is customizable for different needs.

cEM.definition: A version of Ericsson Mediation that is a containerized deployment (as opposed to a virtualized or bare metal deployment - which is known as vEM for Virtualized Ericsson Mediation).

DSN.definition:
Storage Network Detailed Design - 056 01-FDE 105 049

Physically separated network equipment which consists of core, aggregation and access network equipment to deliver storage services to the endpoint server/hypervisor separated from the regular data network.

The DSN network as such is a very small network, that will not see much less frequent changes compared to the internal production network hosting CSN. As such, it is very robust and has a better SLA than the production network.

In this type of network, the most common services are:
- NFS VM Storage Service (recommended)
- LUN Storage Service (recommended)

The DSN should not be connected to other networks in order guarantee service availability. General infrastructure services for example DNS and Active Directory are not available in this network.

DSN is only deployed where it is needed to keep cost and installation footprint small. Radio rooms in the GIC for example will not be equipped with DSN.

Reference: https://erilink.ericsson.se/eridoc/erl/objectId/09004cff8c08d362?docno=BNEP-17:009179Uen&action=current&format=pdf

NCPN.definition:
Cradlepoint’s NetCloud Private Networks (NCPN) is an end-to-end private cellular network solution designed for the needs of today’s dynamic enterprise IT ecosystems. Initially based on the 4G LTE Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) spectrum in the USA, NetCloud Private Networks is a cloud-native solution packaged to make it easy for enterprises to prioritize security and Quality of Service (QoS) while also enabling plug-and-play deployments that scale with an API-first design philosophy.

NetCloud Private Networks provides an added layer of security over and above SIM-based authentication. The added layer of security is built from the ground up using zero-trust principles and is based on a granular and dynamic policy framework that is core to the architecture. The policies are applied based on the connection’s context which includes network, user, device, environment, application, and cellular attributes.

MTRE.definition:
Multitarget Reestab: This column indicates the result of the “MultiTarget re-establishment. Possible values are:
MultiTarget re-establishment REJECTED: It indicates the call attempted to reestablish its connection after a radio link failure, but it was rejected.
MTRE to same cell: It indicates the call reestablished its connection after a radio link failure in the same cell where the radio link failure took place. Note that the Multi-Target RRC Connection Re-Establishment feature extends the basic feature RRC Connection Re-Establishment with more cases where RRC Connection Re-Establishment is supported. Thus, Re-Establishment on the same source cell is considered a particular subcase of Multi-Target RRC Connection Re-Establishment. 
MTRE to Unprepared cell: It indicates the call reestablished its connection after a radio link failure in an unprepared cell.
MTRE to Source cell in HO: It indicates the call reestablished its connection in source cell during ongoing handover.
MTRE to Target cell in HO: It indicates the call reestablished its connection in target cell during ongoing handover.
MTRE to Unprepared cell in HO: It indicates the call reestablished its connection in unprepared cell during ongoing handover.

SCLn.definition:
SCLn pins, also known as Serial Clock pins or I2C Clock pins, are part of the I2C (Inter-Integrated Circuit) bus protocol used for communication between integrated circuits. The number "n" represents the unique identifier for each bus channel of the protocol; for example, SCL0 and SCL1 are different channels. 

SCLn pins are responsible for sending clock signals between devices in order to synchronize the data transfer. The master device generates the clock signals, and the slave devices respond by transmitting data during the appropriate clock cycles. These clock signals are used to ensure that the data is transmitted accurately and efficiently between compatible devices. 

In summary, SCLn pins are a key part of the I2C protocol used for inter-device communication, delivering synchronization signals that enable data to be transferred accurately.
**This description was AI generated**

Reference: https://erilink.ericsson.se/eridoc/erl/objectId/09004cffc5d4817b?action=specific&format=undefined&option=download

The difference between ERH and ENUM is, ENUM is used to process query with local data, while ERH is used to process the query with help from other network nodes, for example, NP databases.

A UI framework that is resolution-independent and uses a vector-based rendering engine, built to take advantage of modern graphics hardware. WPF provides a comprehensive set of application-development features that include Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), controls, data binding, layout, 2D and 3D graphics, animation, styles, templates, documents, media, text, and typography. PVS.definition:
Citrix Provisioning is a software-based streaming technology that can deliver centralized, shared operating system image to multiple virtual or physical endpoints. For design purposes, it is important to understand that PVS is active component - it is actively involved in the daily operations of image management and delivery. As an advantage, Citrix PVS can reduce the operational and storage costs, since it acts as a software-based storage offloading solution. This advantage, however means that the environment needs to be properly designed and maintained. Citrix PVS requires dedicated set of streaming servers, database, and needs to be included in high-availability planning. Design of the PVS environment is mostly hypervisor agnostic and implementations are similar for different hypervisors.

Reference: 
https://docs.citrix.com/en-us/tech-zone/design/design-decisions/image-management.html#overview-of-citrix-provisioning-services-pvs

USV.definition:
User State Virtualization (USV) separates the user’s data and settings from the physical device and replicates it centrally. Microsoft recommends that you start first with User State and Application Virtualization if you plan to incorporate virtualization into your desktop strategy.

User State Virtualization enables user mobility and fast recovery of data in the event a device is lost. Because the data is stored centrally, delivered on demand when the user logs in, and synchronized based on policy configuration, users get their personalized Windows experience immediately regardless of which PC the login into.

Reference:
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/blog/2010/11/30/user-state-virtualization-what-is-it-and-how-will-it-help-you-deliver-a-dynamic-and-personal-windows-experience/#:~:text=To%20recap%2C%20User%20State%20Virtualization,virtualization%20into%20your%20desktop%20strategy.

EIAP.definition:
EIAP is an open platform for multi-vendor, multi-technology RAN automation and orchestration.

It implements Open RAN Service Management and Orchestration (SMO) function and takes this forward on the multi-technology aspect with the capabilities to manage not only Open RAN and Ericsson’s Cloud RAN technology, but purpose-built multi-vendor RAN networks as well.
The platform provides both design and runtime environments for RAN automation use cases across physical and Cloud RAN. The design environment allows for rapid application development and life cycle management of applications. The runtime environment enables multi-vendor applications to run on the platform, access data, and control network elements.

More info:

TGT.definition:
In Kerberos authentication, a Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) is a user authentication token issued by the Key Distribution Center (KDC) that is used to request access tokens from the Ticket Granting Service (TGS) for specific resources/systems joined to the domain.

Use of the TGT was designed into the Kerberos protocol to avoid frequently asking the user for a password – a password used by Kerberos to derive a master key – or storing the master key on the workstation.

Reference: https://doubleoctopus.com/security-wiki/authentication/ticket-granting-tickets/

NTLM.definition:
NTLM authentication is a family of authentication protocols that are encompassed in the Windows Msv1_0.dll. The NTLM authentication protocols include LAN Manager version 1 and 2, and NTLM version 1 and 2. The NTLM authentication protocols authenticate users and computers based on a challenge/response mechanism that proves to a server or domain controller that a user knows the password associated with an account. When the NTLM protocol is used, a resource server must take one of the following actions to verify the identity of a computer or user whenever a new access token is needed:

- Contact a domain authentication service on the domain controller for the computer's or user's account domain, if the account is a domain account.

- Look up the computer's or user's account in the local account database, if the account is a local account.

Reference:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/security/kerberos/ntlm-overview

If the sender and receiver wish to exchange encrypted messages, each must be equipped to encrypt messages to be sent and decrypt messages received.

CEF.definition: The Common Event Format (CEF) is a standardized logging format developed by ArcSight (now part of Micro Focus), a security information and event management (SIEM) solution provider. CEF is designed to simplify the process of logging security-related events and making it easier to integrate logs from different sources into a single system. CEF is based on the syslog format, which is a standard for message logging that is supported by most network devices and operating systems.

CoDel.definition: CoDel (Controlled Delay; pronounced "coddle") is an active queue management (AQM) algorithm in network routing, developed by Van Jacobson and Kathleen Nichols and published as RFC8289

TLP.definition: A meeting where products are tactically discussed and the outcome is product proposals for decisions at the Sales and Operations planning (SoP) meeting.

The Traffic Light Protocol (TLP) was created in order to facilitate greater sharing of information. TLP is a set of designations used to ensure that sensitive information is shared with the appropriate audience. It employs four colors to indicate expected sharing boundaries to be applied by the recipient(s). TLP only has four colors; any designations not listed in this standard are not considered valid by FIRST.

TLP provides a simple and intuitive schema for indicating when and how sensitive information can be shared, facilitating more frequent and effective collaboration. TLP is not a "control marking" or classification scheme. TLP was not designed to handle licensing terms, handling and encryption rules, and restrictions on action or instrumentation of information. TLP labels and their definitions are not intended to have any effect on freedom of information or "sunshine" laws in any jurisdiction.

TLP is optimized for ease of adoption, human readability and person-to-person sharing; it may be used in automated sharing exchanges but is not optimized for that use.

Reference:
https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/news/traffic-light-protocol-tlp-definitions-and-usage#:~:text=TLP%20is%20a%20set%20of,not%20considered%20valid%20by%20FIRST.

In some cases, for performance or efficiency reasons, data can be sent directly to the physical layer to bypass certain network processing steps. This can be useful in certain networking scenarios, such as in high-performance computing or specialized networking applications.

AAD.definition:
************** Important *** *****************************
Microsoft Entra ID is the new name for Azure AD. The names Azure Active Directory, Azure AD, and AAD are replaced with Microsoft Entra ID.
********************************************************

Azure Active Directory is a cloud hosted directory availble for authentication and authorization of many services including Microsoft 365. Azure Active Directory (AAD) groups are useful for authorization of various services configured to access Azure for authentication. Many Azure AD groups are created by Microsoft 365 services like Teams and Distribution Lists as well as some campus systems like Grouper. Many Exchange related groups are synchronized from on-premises Active Directory and these groups can only be updated locally with changes replicated up to Azure. Azure AD groups can be manually created by Departmental Resource Coordinators using the Resource Coordinator Tools. When an Azure AD group is created, the requester is set as an owner. Group owners have the ability to manage group membership and the owners list using the Azure Portal. Azure AD group membership types includ assigned membership, dynamic users and dynamic devices. Assigned membership is the default group type and Resource Coordinators can request the membership type be chaged using the Resource Coordinator Tools website.

Reference:
http://help.mail.colostate.edu/azureadgroups.aspx

TIPC.definition:
TIPC (Transparent Inter Process Communication) is a protocol that is specially designed for intra-cluster communication. It can be configured to transmit messages either on UDP or directly across Ethernet. Message delivery is sequence guaranteed, loss free and flow controlled. Latency times are shorter than with any other known protocol, while maximal throughput is comparable to that of TCP.
http://www.tipc.io/intro.html
https://docs.kernel.org/networking/tipc.html

RSF.definition:
From https://eteamspace.internal.ericsson.com/display/PB/R-State+Factory 

- - - -

R-State Factory: https://rsf.sero.wh.rnd.internal.ericsson.com/

The purpose of using RSF is two fold.

The simple reason is to guarantee that only R-states valid according to Ericsson Corporate Basic Standards are used in the CI environment. This is important to ensure that the product/UP and its components are releasable through the Ericsson process and systems.

The other reason is to simplify release branching and the communication between node CI and module CI about when R-state series should change according to the recommended G1 branching strategy or G2 branching strategy. The branching strategy ensures that there always is an available R-state series available for the UP and the modules/LMCs for any track that the development/release project needs to maintain and request corrections on.

Important to note is that RSF tracks all products individually based on their product number and the track name. There is no information of product relations or product structure, that should be kept in other information systems like Infobank, DW2, Event Repository or PRIM

vVols.definition:
VMware vSphere Virtual Volumes (vVols) is a storage area network (SAN)/network-attached storage (NAS) management and integration framework that exposes virtual disks as native storage objects and enables array-based operations at the virtual disk level.

vVols transform the data plane of SAN/NAS devices by aligning storage consumptions and operations with the VM. In other words, vVols make SAN/NAS devices VM-aware and unlocks the ability to leverage array-based data services with a VM-centric approach at the granularity of a single virtual disk.

vVols allows organizations to leverage the unique capabilities of their current storage investments and transition without disruption to a simpler and more efficient operational model optimized for virtual environments that work across all storage types.

SPBM.definition: Storage Policy-Based Management (SPBM) allows capturing storage service-level requirements, such as capacity, performance, or availability, in the form of logical templates (policies) to which VMs are associated. SPBM automates VM placement by identifying available data stores that meet policy requirements; coupled with vVols, it dynamically instantiates necessary data services. Through policy enforcement, SPBM also automates service-level monitoring and compliance throughout the life cycle of the VM.

DRaaS.definition:
Disaster recovery as a service (DRaaS) is a cloud computing service model offered by third-party vendors that provides failover in the event of a natural catastrophe, power outage or other type of business disruption.

DRaaS offers an off-site disaster recovery (DR) capability that lets customers avoid the cost of maintaining secondary data centers. The approach has opened DR to organizations that wouldn't have been able to afford such a capability in the past.

Typically, DRaaS requirements and expectations are documented in a service-level agreement (SLA), and the third-party vendor provides failover to a cloud computing environment, either through a contract or on a pay-per-use basis. In the event of an actual disaster, an off-site vendor is less likely than the enterprise itself to suffer the direct and immediate effects, which enables the provider to implement the customer's DR plan even in the event of the worst-case scenario -- a total or near-total shutdown of the affected enterprise.

Reference:
https://www.techtarget.com/searchdisasterrecovery/definition/disaster-recovery-as-a-service-DRaaS

VBS.definition:
Virtualization-based security, or VBS, uses hardware virtualization and the Windows hypervisor to create an isolated virtual environment that becomes the root of trust of the OS that assumes the kernel can be compromised. Windows uses this isolated environment to host a number of security solutions, providing them with greatly increased protection from vulnerabilities in the operating system, and preventing the use of malicious exploits which attempt to defeat protections. VBS enforces restrictions to protect vital system and operating system resources, or to protect security assets such as authenticated user credentials.

One such example security solution is memory integrity, which protects and hardens Windows by running kernel mode code integrity within the isolated virtual environment of VBS. Kernel mode code integrity is the Windows process that checks all kernel mode drivers and binaries before they're started, and prevents unsigned or untrusted drivers or system files from being loaded into system memory. Memory integrity also restricts kernel memory allocations that could be used to compromise the system, ensuring that kernel memory pages are only made executable after passing code integrity checks inside the secure runtime environment, and executable pages themselves are never writable. That way, even if there are vulnerabilities like a buffer overflow that allow malware to attempt to modify memory, executable code pages cannot be modified, and modified memory cannot be made executable.

Reference:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/design/device-experiences/oem-vbs

HVCI.definition:
Memory integrity is sometimes referred to as hypervisor-protected code integrity (HVCI) or hypervisor enforced code integrity, and was originally released as part of Device Guard. Device Guard is no longer used except to locate memory integrity and VBS settings in Group Policy or the Windows registry.

Reference:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/design/device-experiences/oem-vbs

FBL.definition:
The Farm Behavior Level (FBL) is a farm-wide setting that determines the features the Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) farm can use. It was introduced in Windows Server 2016. By default, the FBL in a new AD FS farm matches the value for the Windows Server version of the first farm node installed. You can join an AD FS server of a later version to a farm with a lower FBL. The farm operates at the same FBL as the existing node(s).

If you’re looking to upgrade the farm behavior level for AD FS, you can follow the instructions provided in the Microsoft Learn article. The article provides detailed information on prerequisites, farm behavior levels, and upgrading federation servers.

Reference:
As per "Bing, AI-powered copilot for the web"

S2D.definition:
Storage Spaces Direct is a feature of Azure Stack HCI and Windows Server that enables you to cluster servers with internal storage into a software-defined storage solution.

Storage Spaces Direct is a software-defined storage solution that allows you to share storage resources in your converged and hyperconverged IT infrastructure. It enables you to combine internal storage drives on a cluster of physical servers (2 and up to 16) into a software-defined pool of storage. This storage pool has cache, tiers, resiliency, and erasure coding across columns—all configured and managed automatically.

You can scale out the storage capacity of your cluster by adding more drives or adding more servers in the cluster. Storage Spaces Direct automatically onboards the new drives and rebalances the storage pool. It also automatically uses the fastest storage media present to provide built-in and always-on cache.

Reference:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure-stack/hci/concepts/storage-spaces-direct-overview

kSup.definition:

Subscriptions are the unit type used to define quantity of value packages. One subscription shall be purchased for each unique identity per use-case that wants to make use of these specific packages. Unique identity can be: 
–	MSISDN or IMSI
–	ISDN (B-channel/D-channel)
–	Fixed line number (PSTN/POTS)
–	Username/password for xDSL
–	Static IP address
–	Terminal identifier for other wireless mobile technologies like CDMA, NMT, etc.

Used in terms of licensing - for Ericsson Mediation and perhaps other software.

– If the same (duplicated or reformatted, not otherwise changed) data record is distributed to multiple destinations across domains it shall be counted once per domain.

PCP PLATFORM.definition:
Programmable Cloud Platform enables the deployment of hardware tasks on a programmable platform through standard cloud infrastructure. Programmable logic has attracted the interest of major data center operators who find the performance gains it offers appealing but are put off by the high development effort and risk together with the lack of proper integration into existing cloud environments.

PCP Platform addresses these concerns by offering both hardware and software modules, on which the hardware tasks can be deployed on the programmable fabric with the help of software running on a standard, low-power ARM processor.

The rest of the time the device can remain in sleep mode.

OSSii.definition:
OSSii – Operations Support Systems interoperability initiative was initiated in May 2013 to promote OSS interoperability between different OSS vendor’s equipment.

Operations Support Systems integrate to a variety of telecom network technologies from several equipment vendors as well as the telecom operator business systems, making the integration of OSS complex and costly.

The objectives of OSSii is to enable and simplify interoperability between OSS systems, reducing overall OSS integration costs and enabling shorter time-to-market.

The OSSii portal is used to communicate the OSSii initiative and intent, and to provide information about the OSSii principles. See https://www.ossii.net

https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/cloud-private/3.1.1?topic=storage-understanding-kubernetes

Kubernetes supports three kinds of access modes for PVs: ReadWriteOnce, ReadOnlyMany, and ReadWriteMany.

ReadWriteOnce (RWO) - the volume can be mounted as read/write by a single node

ReadOnlyMany (ROX) - the volume can be mounted as read-only by multiple nodes

ReadWriteMany (RWX) - the volume can be mounted as read/write by multiple nodes

RDBMS.definition: relational database management system (RDBMS) is a collection of programs and capabilities that enable IT teams and others to create, update, administer and otherwise interact with a relational database.

GSLB.definition:
Global Server Load Balancing (GSLB) enables multi-data center and multi-cloud resilience by leveraging service resource awareness and DNS to steer traffic across geographically distributed pools based on defined business logic. When deployed across multiple data centers, it provides application load balancing at geographic scale – across town or across the globe – using any mix of hardware, virtual and cloud platforms. GSLB provides multi-site resilience with seamless failover and failback in the event of a critical resource failure as well as offering optimised redirection of traffic to the closest physical service location. In the event of a service disruption, traffic is automatically redirected based on predefined policies to minimize impact and the need for manual intervention.

Client traffic is sent to the location that will provide the very best application performance and client experience, tailored to the location of the client and the observed availability of each location. The client traffic redirection can be further refined using EDNS (Extension Mechanisms for DNS) to provide fine-grained control on which available locations a client is directed based on their source subnet.

Providing these services locally is a cost-effective alternative to providing these services using in-house resources or contracting with expensive hosted Domain Name Service (DNS) services that don’t provide the flexibility and control that you require. Services like company email, remote desktop environments, and other managed resources where user experience, high availability, and disaster recovery are mission critical.

Reference:
https://kemptechnologies.com/fr/global-server-load-balancing-gslb

OII.definition:
Organizational Identifiable Information (OII) refers to data that organizations collect and use for various purposes. While it is similar to Personally Identifiable Information (PII), there are some distinctions.

- OII includes data that organizations collect during their regular - activities.

- It may not directly identify an individual but is still essential for organizational operations.

- Examples of OII include:
  - Tenant ID (used in cloud services)
  - Object ID for service principals
  - Scope names

- While OII is not as sensitive as PII, organizations must still handle it carefully to maintain security and compliance.

RID.definition: Routing Indicator (RID) is part of SUCI. RID is stored in USIM.  Otherwise, ME uses Default RID value (0) if RID not available in USIM. Default RID value (0) is interpreted as any AUSF/UDM within the HPLMN of the UE can be selected. RID is used to assist AMF in AUSF/UDM selection when the HPLMN is segmented and the SUPI privacy feature is used in the HPLMN.  3GPP defines that when AMF receives a SUCI, the AMF stores the RID and provides it to other AMFs within the UE context. Additionally, it is defined that AMF provides the RID to SMF/SMSF to facilitate the UDM selection.

PKCE is a simple, lightweight mechanism that can be implemented in any application that requests an authorization code. PKCE is pronounced “pixie”

OData.definition:
OData (Open Data Protocol) is an ISO/IEC approved, OASIS standard that defines a set of best practices for building and consuming RESTful APIs. OData helps you focus on your business logic while building RESTful APIs without having to worry about the various approaches to define request and response headers, status codes, HTTP methods, URL conventions, media types, payload formats, query options, etc. OData also provides guidance for tracking changes, defining functions/actions for reusable procedures, and sending asynchronous/batch requests.

OData RESTful APIs are easy to consume. The OData metadata, a machine-readable description of the data model of the APIs, enables the creation of powerful generic client proxies and tools.

TCP segmentation offload (TSO) is an optimization technique that reduces the CPU overhead in TCP/IP-related network operations. With TSO enabled, a network internet controller (NIC) splits large data chunks traveling over a network into smaller TCP segments. Without TSO, the segmentation is performed by the CPU, which creates an overhead. TSO is also known as LSO (Large Segment Offload).

BSON.definition:
BSON, short for Bin­ary JSON, is a bin­ary-en­coded seri­al­iz­a­tion of JSON-like doc­u­ments. Like JSON, BSON sup­ports the em­bed­ding of doc­u­ments and ar­rays with­in oth­er doc­u­ments and ar­rays. BSON also con­tains ex­ten­sions that al­low rep­res­ent­a­tion of data types that are not part of the JSON spec. For ex­ample, BSON has a Date type and a BinData type.

BSON can be com­pared to bin­ary inter­change for­mats, like Proto­col Buf­fers. BSON is more "schema-less" than Proto­col Buf­fers, which can give it an ad­vant­age in flex­ib­il­ity but also a slight dis­ad­vant­age in space ef­fi­ciency (BSON has over­head for field names with­in the seri­al­ized data).

Reference:
https://bsonspec.org/

M-TMSI.definition:
The M-TMSI (MME Temporary Mobile Subscriber Identity) is a unique identifier assigned by the Mobile Management Entity (MME) to a mobile device or subscriber when it registers with LTE network.
The M-TMSI serves as a temporary identity for preserving subscriber confidentiality.
It masks the International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), which can otherwise be used to track a subscriber’s location and other personal information.
By using the M-TMSI, the LTE network can protect the subscriber’s privacy while still managing mobility and allocating resources.

HIDS.definition: A Host-based Intrusion Detection System (HIDS) consist of detection functionality deployed on the end hosts, which is controlled through the configuration of a ruleset. This ruleset can vary greatly in how extensive it is. Segmenting an extensive ruleset and dynamically expanding when a minimal ruleset is triggered may help decrease performance overhead on the node during normal runtime. Splitting an extensive ruleset into cohesive segments comes with a unique set of challenges when it comes to ruleset expansion and pattern detection.
